4	"Senate Democrats dropped their objections Friday night to a short-term-funding bill to keep the government running
column2: and the bill passed less than an hour before the midnight deadline.

column1: It's become a familiar year-end act for Congress: passing a short-term-funding bill that will keep the government running for a few more months. This funding measure
column2: which passed 63-36
column3: runs out in April.

column1: Despite overwhelming support in the House on Thursday
column2: the spending package hit a roadblock in the Senate
column3: where coal state Democrats staged a late protest to try to alter provisions affecting miners.

column1: The stopgap includes $45 million to continue health benefits for four months for certain retired coal miners
column2: whose coverage was set to expire at the end of the year. Democrats
column3: led by West Virginia's Joe Manchin
column4: wanted a full-year extension
column5: but with little leverage and a shutdown looming
column6: they relented with a promise to reignite that fight in four months.

column1: Would I have preferred that provision to be more generous? Of course I would have
column2: said Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell. ""But we'll be back at it in April
column3: and I think it's highly unlikely that we'll take it away.""

column1: With House lawmakers already back home for the holidays on Friday ÃÂ and zero interest from GOP leaders to reopen negotiations ÃÂ Democrats backed down in time to avert a midnight Friday shutdown.

The spending bill keeps the federal government running on autopilot until April 28. Congressional Republicans opted to punt the annual spending bills into next year to wait until President-elect Donald Trump assumes office. With control of both the White House and Congress
column2: Republicans will have more sway over how roughly $1 trillion is spent on federal agencies and programs.

column1: The bill runs through April to buy Congress more time to negotiate the fiscal year 2017 spending bills
column2: because the Senate is expected to be consumed by the confirmation process for Trump administration nominees in the first quarter of next year.

column1: Since the spending bill is a must-pass measure
column2: it also includes some unrelated provisions and additional funding measures. For instance
column3: Senate Republicans included language that will help expedite the confirmation process for Trump's defense secretary nominee
column4: retired Gen. James Mattis.

column1: For Mattis to be confirmed
column2: Congress must waive a law that requires a seven-year cooling-off period for current or former military officials to hold that Cabinet post. Mattis retired in 2013.

column1: Democrats objected to the language
column2: but Republicans said it was necessary to expedite consideration of a critical administration post. The waiver will still be reviewed by the House and Senate Armed Services Committees
column3: and it will need to pass a 60-vote threshold in the Senate.

column1: Mattis has been widely praised on both sides of the aisle and is expected to be confirmed
column2: barring something unforeseen coming to light during the confirmation process.

column1: The measure also includes just over $10 billion in Overseas Contingency Funding
column2: better known as the side Pentagon account that funds the ongoing war efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan.

column1: An additional $4.1 billion is directed to disaster relief
column2: including recovery efforts from Hurricane Matthew.

column1: Democrats also secured funding to assist the Flint
column2: Mich.
column3: community with repairing its drinking water systems. Some $170 million is directed toward infrastructure improvements and preventive care against lead poisoning for mothers and children.

column1: Congress approved a biomedical research bill this week
column2: and the stopgap spending measure includes funds for new programs authorized in the legislation
column3: such as $352 million to the National Institutes of Health for medical research and $500 million to states to combat the opioid epidemic.

column1: The measure also includes a provision that will prevent a pay raise for members of Congress. The pay freeze has been in place since 2010."	0

column1: Mindless entertainment.

column2: every day
column3: watching TV. After sleep

column3: tablets

column1: If you spend 5-8 hours a day

column4: we have devoted 5-8 hours a day staring at a screen ÃÂ every day. And we havenÃÂt been watching Judy Woodruff. We have been watching reality TV shows. That is what we love. That is what we resonate to. ÃÂThe Real Housewives of Atlanta.ÃÂ

column2: early television was allowed

column5: ÃÂ carefully and quietly commentating on what they saw way down below. They did not get involved in the process. Today
column6: they ARE the process. Today
column7: political conventions are nothing but carefully directed TV shows. Likewise ÃÂdebates.ÃÂ They exist only to entertain a TV audience. TV and entertainment now dictate everything political. It is a never-ending show. The biggest reality show on air.

column1: And Donald Trump is great TV.

Hillary Clinton is crap TV.
She may be smarter
column2: better prepared

column6: we can safely say

105	As President-elect Donald Trump prepares to be sworn in as the country's commander-in-chief next month
column2: a majority of Americans say they are either uncertain or pessimistic about his presidency
column3: even as the country is sounding a more optimistic tone about the future of the economy and Trump's ability to bring positive change to Washington D.C.

column1: A new NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll finds 54 percent of adults saying that they are either uncertain (25 percent) or pessimistic and worried (29 percent) about how Trump will perform during his presidency
column2: compared with 45 percent with either an optimistic and confident view (22 percent) or a satisfied and hopeful view (23 percent).

column1: That's a significantly worse outlook than Americans expressed after the elections of both Barack Obama and George W. Bush. A combined 66 percent were either optimistic or hopeful about Obama in January 2009
column2: according to the same poll
column3: while 59 percent were optimistic or hopeful about George W. Bush in January 2001.

column1: The data show the extent to which the nation remains unusually divided even though Election Day is in the rearview mirror
column2: said Democratic pollster Fred Yang of Hart Research Associates
column3: which conducted this survey with Republican pollster Bill McInturff and his firm Public Opinion Strategies.

column1: Usually elections settle arguments and the nation comes together
column2: at least in the short term
column3: Yang said. ""Today
column4: hard feelings persist on both sides of the partisan divide. It's as if the 2016 campaign has never ended.""

column1: Those partisan differences are particularly stark when it comes to public approval ratings of the way Trump is handling his transition. Half of the country overall gives Trump high marks so far
column2: compared to 41 percent who give him a thumbs down. But among Hillary Clinton's voters
column3: only 12 percent approve of how he's handling the transition
column4: compared to 92 percent of Trump voters.

column1: Back in 2008
column2: 50 percent of John McCain's voters approved of Barack Obama's handling of his presidential transition
column3: and in 1992
column4: 63 percent of George H.W. Bush's voters backed Bill Clinton's early moves as president-elect.

column1: The partisan divide extends to views about the men and women Trump has selected to lead his administration. Seventy-eight percent of Democrats say they are disappointed with the administration appointments Trump has made so far
column2: while 80 percent of Republicans say they are generally pleased with Trump's picks.

column1: While Trump's overall favorability has ticked up modestly since before the election
column2: he remains underwater
column3: with more Americans giving him a poor rating (46 percent) than a positive one (40 percent.)

column1: That marks the first time that an incoming president has been viewed more negatively than positively in the history of the NBC/WSJ poll.
Some bright spots -- but ones mostly driven by enthusiasm from Trump's supporters
While the public is largely apprehensive about the president-elect
column2: Americans do say that they are more optimistic that the U.S. economy will improve in the next year. Forty-two percent say they believe the economy will get better - the highest share since autumn of 2012 -- while only 19 percent say the economy will get worse in the next year.

column1: Trump has also generated relatively positive feelings about his ability to change the federal government for the better. A majority of Americans say Trump will shake up the way government operates - and
column2: among that group
column3: they believe that he'll bring the right kind of change by a two-to-one margin (41 percent to 20 percent).

column1: Additionally
column2: a majority - fifty-six percent - say they are optimistic that Trump will keep U.S. jobs from going overseas.

column1: Still
column2: the confidence about Trump's presidency is mostly fueled by enthusiasm among his base voters rather than by more hopeful expectations among those who didn't choose him on their ballot in November.

column1: A whopping 92 percent of Trump voters are optimistic about his ability to bring change to Washington
column2: while just 20 percent of Clinton voters say the same. The same share of Trump voters - 92 percent - say they are hopeful that Trump will look out for those who are struggling in today's economy
column3: while only nine percent of Clinton voters agree.

column1: Those who say that the economy will get better in the next year rather than worse include key Trump constituency groups like whites (49 percent better compared to 15 percent worse)
column2: Republicans (68 percent better to six percent worse)
column3: and men (46 percent better to 15 percent worse.) Among Democrats
column4: 33 percent believe the economy will get worse compared to 19 percent who believe it will improve
column5: and just 22 percent of African Americans think the economy will improve compared to a third who say it will deteriorate.

column1: The public also still harbors concerns about Trump's temperament. Just 36 percent of Americans say they are optimistic that Trump has the right temperament to be president

column1: The Republican Party gets a boost - but will it last?

column3: 38 percent negative) than the Democratic Party (34 percent positive
column4: 42 percent negative). That's the first time since after the 2010 midterms that Republicans have scored better on the favorability measure than their Democratic counterparts.

column1: But it's not clear that Americans' warmer feelings toward the GOP will endure. After its previous high watermark six years ago
column2: the party's positive ratings quickly fell back to earth
column3: with Democrats regaining the advantage the following month."	0

column1: Some Republicans would revise and rebrand Obamacare

column1: Can Congress put aside differences in the new year?
Play VIDEO
Can Congress put aside differences in the new year?

President-elect Donald Trump and Republican congressional leaders will have to unite the groups on complicated changes affecting the financial and physical well-being of millions of people. For some constituents in fragile health
column2: itÃÂs literally a life-and-death debate.

column1: Republicans have ÃÂa really narrow path
column2: ÃÂ says Grace-Marie Turner of the Galen Institute
column3: a free-market health care research organization. ÃÂTheyÃÂve got to deal with the politics of this
column4: theyÃÂve got to make sure they come up with good policy
column5: and they also have process challenges.ÃÂ

column1: Success is not guaranteed
column2: and Republicans may come to regret that their party defined itself as totally opposed to Obamacare.

column1: Yet House Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady seems unfazed by the challenge. ÃÂItÃÂs like tax reform
column2: ÃÂ says Brady
column3: a Texas Republican
column4: explaining that many pieces will be pulled together. ÃÂUnlike Obamacare
column5: which ripped up the individual market
column6: this will be done deliberately
column7: in an appropriate timetable.ÃÂ

column1: Republicans say they will move quickly to repeal the ACA
column2: while suspending the effective date to allow them to craft a replacement. HereÃÂs a look at the GOP camps and whoÃÂs in them:

column1: Revise and rebrand
Many Republicans may quietly be in this contingent
column2: but fear being accused of promoting Obamacare-lite.

column1: TheyÃÂd strip out some of the ACAÃÂs taxes and requirements. The unpopular individual mandate to carry health insurance or risk fines could be replaced with other persuasion short of a government dictate. Rules on insurers would be loosened.
But popular provisions such as protecting those with pre-existing health conditions would be retained in some form
column2: as well as financial assistance for low- and moderate-income people. The requirement that health plans cover adult children until age 26 would be fairly easy to preserve
column3: since employers have accommodated it.

column1: A rebranded version of ObamaÃÂs law may well cover fewer people. But its GOP advocates believe most Americans will find their goal of universal access to care politically acceptable when measured against the Democratic ideal of universal coverage
column2: underwritten by government.

column1: Budget hawks

column1: 146	"Let us now address the greatest American mystery at the moment: what motivates the supporters of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump?

column2: filling stadiums and airport hangars
column3: but their views
column4: by and large
column5: do not appear in our prestige newspapers. On their opinion pages
column6: these publications take care to represent demographic categories of nearly every kind

column8: he made one up

column1: When members of the professional class wish to understand the working-class Other

He wants to bar Muslims from visiting the United States. He admires various foreign strongmen and dictators

column1: All this stuff is so insane

column7: racial superiority

column1: Stories marveling at the stupidity of Trump voters are published nearly every day. Articles that accuse TrumpÃÂs followers of being bigots have appeared by the hundreds
column2: if not the thousands. Conservatives have written them; liberals have written them; impartial professionals have written them. The headline of a recent Huffington Post column announced
column3: bluntly
column4: that ÃÂTrump Won Super Tuesday Because America is Racist.ÃÂ A New York Times reporter proved that TrumpÃÂs followers were bigots by coordinating a map of Trump support with a map of racist Google searches. Everyone knows it: TrumpÃÂs followersÃÂ passions are nothing more than the ignorant blurtings of the white American id
column5: driven to madness by the presence of a black man in the White House. The Trump movement is a one-note phenomenon
column6: a vast surge of race-hate. Its partisans are not only incomprehensible
column7: they are not really worth comprehending.

column1: Or so weÃÂre told. Last week
column2: I decided to watch several hours of Trump speeches for myself. I saw the man ramble and boast and threaten and even seem to gloat when protesters were ejected from the arenas in which he spoke. I was disgusted by these things
column3: as I have been disgusted by Trump for 20 years. But I also noticed something surprising. In each of the speeches I watched
column4: Trump spent a good part of his time talking about an entirely legitimate issue
column5: one that could even be called leftwing.

column1: Yes
column2: Donald Trump talked about trade. In fact
column3: to judge by how much time he spent talking about it
column4: trade may be his single biggest concern ÃÂ not white supremacy. Not even his plan to build a wall along the Mexican border
column5: the issue that first won him political fame. He did it again during the debate on 3 March: asked about his political excommunication by Mitt Romney
column6: he chose to pivot and talk about ÃÂ trade.

column1: It seems to obsess him: the destructive free-trade deals our leaders have made
column2: the many companies that have moved their production facilities to other lands
column3: the phone calls he will make to those companiesÃÂ CEOs in order to threaten them with steep tariffs unless they move back to the US.

column1: Trump embellished this vision with another favorite leftwing idea: under his leadership
column2: the government would ÃÂstart competitive bidding in the drug industryÃÂ. (ÃÂWe donÃÂt competitively bid!ÃÂ he marveled ÃÂ another true fact
column3: a legendary boondoggle brought to you by the George W Bush administration.) Trump extended the critique to the military-industrial complex
column4: describing how the government is forced to buy lousy but expensive airplanes thanks to the power of industry lobbyists.

column2: a fact about which he loves to boast
column3: Trump himself is unaffected by business lobbyists and donations. And because he is free from the corrupting power of modern campaign finance
column4: famous deal-maker Trump can make deals on our behalf that are ÃÂgoodÃÂ instead of ÃÂbadÃÂ. The chance that he will actually do so

column1: All this surprised me because
column2: for all the articles about Trump I had read in recent months
column3: I didnÃÂt recall trade coming up very often. Trump is supposed to be on a one-note crusade for whiteness. Could it be that all this trade stuff is a key to understanding the Trump phenomenon?

column1: Trade is an issue that polarizes Americans by socio-economic status. To the professional class
column2: which encompasses the vast majority of our media figures
column3: economists
column4: Washington officials and Democratic powerbrokers
column5: what they call ÃÂfree tradeÃÂ is something so obviously good and noble it doesnÃÂt require explanation or inquiry or even thought. Republican and Democratic leaders alike agree on this
column6: and no amount of facts can move them from their Econ 101 dream.

column1: To the remaining 80 or 90% of America
column2: trade means something very different. ThereÃÂs a video going around on the internet these days that shows a room full of workers at a Carrier air conditioning plant in Indiana being told by an officer of the company that the factory is being moved to Monterrey
column3: Mexico
column4: and that theyÃÂre all going to lose their jobs.

column1: As I watched it

The Carrier executive talks in that familiar and highly professional HR language about the need to ÃÂstay competitiveÃÂ and ÃÂthe extremely price-sensitive marketplaceÃÂ. A worker shouts ÃÂFuck you!ÃÂ at the executive. The executive asks people to please be quiet so he can ÃÂshareÃÂ his ÃÂinformationÃÂ. His information about all of them losing their jobs.

column1: Now

column1: But there is another way to interpret the Trump phenomenon. A map of his support may coordinate with racist Google searches
column2: but it coordinates even better with deindustrialization and despair
column3: with the zones of economic misery that 30 years of WashingtonÃÂs free-market consensus have brought the rest of America.

column1: It is worth noting that Trump is making a point of assailing that Indiana air conditioning company from the video in his speeches. What this suggests is that heÃÂs telling a tale as much about economic outrage as it is tale of racism on the march. Many of TrumpÃÂs followers are bigots
column2: no doubt
column3: but many more are probably excited by the prospect of a president who seems to mean it when he denounces our trade agreements and promises to bring the hammer down on the CEO that fired you and wrecked your town
column4: unlike Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton.

column1: Here is the most salient supporting fact: when people talk to white
column2: working-class Trump supporters
column3: instead of simply imagining what they might say
column4: they find that what most concerns these people is the economy and their place in it. I am referring to a study just published by Working America
column5: a political-action auxiliary of the AFL-CIO
column6: which interviewed some 1
column7: 600 white working-class voters in the suburbs of Cleveland and Pittsburgh in December and January.

column1: Support for Donald Trump
column2: the group found
column3: ran strong among these people
column4: even among self-identified Democrats
column5: but not because they are all pining for a racist in the White House. Their favorite aspect of Trump was his ÃÂattitudeÃÂ
column6: the blunt and forthright way he talks. As far as issues are concerned
column7: ÃÂimmigrationÃÂ placed third among the matters such voters care about
column8: far behind their number one concern: ÃÂgood jobs / the economyÃÂ.

column1: ÃÂPeople are much more frightened than they are bigoted
column2: ÃÂ is how the findings were described to me by Karen Nussbaum
column3: the executive director of Working America. The survey ÃÂconfirmed what we heard all the time: people are fed up
column4: people are hurting
column5: they are very distressed about the fact that their kids donÃÂt have a futureÃÂ and that ÃÂthere still hasnÃÂt been a recovery from the recession
column6: that every family still suffers from it in one way or another.ÃÂ

column1: Tom Lewandowski
column2: the president of the Northeast Indiana Central Labor Council in Fort Wayne
column3: puts it even more bluntly when I asked him about working-class Trump fans. ÃÂThese people arenÃÂt racist
column4: not any more than anybody else is
column5: ÃÂ he says of Trump supporters he knows. ÃÂWhen Trump talks about trade
column6: we think about the Clinton administration
column7: first with Nafta and then with [Permanent Normal Trade Relations] China
column8: and here in Northeast Indiana
column9: we hemorrhaged jobs.ÃÂ

column1: ÃÂThey look at that
column2: and hereÃÂs Trump talking about trade
column3: in a ham-handed way
column4: but at least heÃÂs representing emotionally. WeÃÂve had all the political establishment standing behind every trade deal
column5: and we endorsed some of these people
column6: and then weÃÂve had to fight them to get them to represent us.ÃÂ

column1: Now
column2: let us stop and smell the perversity. Left parties the world over were founded to advance the fortunes of working people. But our left party in America ÃÂ one of our two monopoly parties ÃÂ chose long ago to turn its back on these peopleÃÂs concerns
column3: making itself instead into the tribune of the enlightened professional class
column4: a ÃÂcreative classÃÂ that makes innovative things like derivative securities and smartphone apps. The working people that the party used to care about
column5: Democrats figured

column7: in the famous Clinton-era expression. The party just didnÃÂt need to listen to them any longer.

column1: What Lewandowski and Nussbaum are saying
column2: then
column3: should be obvious to anyone whoÃÂs dipped a toe outside the prosperous enclaves on the two coasts. Ill-considered trade deals and generous bank bailouts and guaranteed profits for insurance companies but no recovery for average people
column4: ever ÃÂ these policies have taken their toll. As Trump says
column5: ÃÂwe have rebuilt China and yet our country is falling apart. Our infrastructure is falling apart ÃÂ Our airports are
column6: like
column7: Third World.ÃÂ

column1: TrumpÃÂs words articulate the populist backlash against liberalism that has been building slowly for decades and may very well occupy the White House itself
column2: whereupon the entire world will be required to take seriously its demented ideas.

column1: Yet still we cannot bring ourselves to look the thing in the eyes. We cannot admit that we liberals bear some of the blame for its emergence

column1: 152	"There is a smug style in American liberalism. It has been growing these past decades. It is a way of conducting politics
column2: predicated on the belief that American life is not divided by moral difference or policy divergence ÃÂ not really ÃÂ but by the failure of half the country to know what's good for them.
the smug style has found expression in media and in policy
column3: in the attitudes of liberals both visible and private
column4: providing a foundational set of assumptions above which a great number of liberals comport their understanding of the world.

column1: It has led an American ideology hitherto responsible for a great share of the good accomplished over the past century of our political life to a posture of reaction and disrespect: a condescending
column2: defensive sneer toward any person or movement outside of its consensus
column3: dressed up as a monopoly on reason.

column1: The smug style is a psychological reaction to a profound shift in American political demography.
Beginning in the middle of the 20th century
column2: the working class
column3: once the core of the coalition
column4: began abandoning the Democratic Party. In 1948
column5: in the immediate wake of Franklin Roosevelt
column6: 66 percent of manual laborers voted for Democrats
column7: along with 60 percent of farmers. In 1964
column8: it was 55 percent of working-class voters. By 1980
column9: it was 35 percent.

column1: The white working class in particular saw even sharper declines. Despite historic advantages with both poor and middle-class white voters
column2: by 2012 Democrats possessed only a 2-point advantage among poor white voters. Among white voters making between $30
column4: 000 per year
column5: the GOP has taken a 17-point lead.

column1: Finding comfort in the notion that their former allies were disdainful
column2: hapless rubes
column3: smug liberals created a culture animated by that contempt

column1: The consequence was a shift in liberalism's intellectual center of gravity. A movement once fleshed out in union halls and little magazines shifted into universities and major press
column2: from the center of the country to its cities and elite enclaves. Minority voters remained
column3: but bereft of the material and social capital required to dominate elite decision-making
column4: they were largely excluded from an agenda driven by the new Democratic core: the educated
column5: the coastal
column6: and the professional.

column1: It is not that these forces captured the party so much as it fell to them. When the laborer left
column2: they remained.

column1: The origins of this shift are overdetermined. Richard Nixon bears a large part of the blame
column2: but so does Bill Clinton. The Southern Strategy
column3: yes
column4: but the destruction of labor unions
column5: too. I have my own sympathies
column6: but I do not propose to adjudicate that question here.

column1: Suffice it to say
column2: by the 1990s the better part of the working class wanted nothing to do with the word liberal. What remained of the American progressive elite was left to puzzle: What happened to our coalition?

column1: Why did they abandon us?
What's the matter with Kansas?
The smug style arose to answer these questions. It provided an answer so simple and so emotionally satisfying that its success was perhaps inevitable: the theory that conservatism
column2: and particularly the kind embraced by those out there in the country
column3: was not a political ideology at all.

How politics makes us stupid

The trouble is that stupid hicks don't know what's good for them. They're getting conned by right-wingers and tent revivalists until they believe all the lies that've made them so wrong. They don't know any better. That's why they're voting against their own self-interest.
As anybody who has gone through a particularly nasty breakup knows

column3: the blame is reason enough to keep them at a distance
column4: the excuse to drive them even further away.

column1: Finding comfort in the notion that their former allies were disdainful

column1: The smug style resists empathy for the unknowing. It denies the possibility of a politics whereby those who do not share knowing culture
column2: who do not like the right things or know the Good Facts or recognize the intellectual bankruptcy of their own ideas can be worked with
column3: in spite of these differences

column1: The wages of smug is Trump.

Nothing is more confounding to the smug style than the fact that the average Republican is better educated and has a higher IQ than the average Democrat. That for every overpowered study finding superior liberal open-mindedness and intellect and knowledge
column2: there is one to suggest that Republicans have the better of these qualities.

column2: perhaps
column3: to the fancy liberal self-conception: Republicans score higher in susceptibility to persuasion. They are willing to change their minds more often.

column2: smart enough
column3: informed enough.

column1: The Democratic coalition in the 21st century is bifurcated: It has the postgraduates
column2: but it has the disenfranchised urban poor as well
column3: a group better defined by race and immigration status than by class. There are more Americans without high school diplomas than in possession of doctoral degrees. The math proceeds from there.

column2: and the Democratic Party by extension
column3: cannot hate poor people
column4: they say. We aren't smug! Just look at our coalition. These aren't rubes. Just look at our embrace of their issues.

column2: another kind of knowing. Mere awareness of these issues becomes the most important thing
column3: the capacity to articulate them a new subset of Correct Facts.

column2: that knowing ÃÂ or knowing
column3: no inflection ÃÂ did make our political divide. That the problem is the rubes. That the dumbass hicks are to blame. They can't help it: Their brains don't work. They isolate themselves from all the Good Facts
column4: and they're being taken for a ride by con men.

column1: Pretend the ridicule worked too: that the videos and the Twitter burns and destroying the opposition made all the bad guys go away.

What kind of world would it leave us? An endless cycle of jokes? Of sick burns and smart tweets and knowing? Relative to whom? The smug style demands an object of disdain; it would find a new one quickly.
It is central to the liberal self-conception that what separates them from reactionaries is a desire to help people
column2: a desire to create a fairer and more just world. Liberals still want
column3: or believe they still want
column4: to make a more perfect union.

column1: Whether you believe they are deluded or not
column2: whether you believe this project is worthwhile in any form or not
column3: what I am trying to tell you is that the smug style has fundamentally undermined even the aspiration
column4: that it has made American liberalism into the worst version of itself.

column1: It is impossible
column2: in the long run
column3: to cleave the desire to help people from the duty to respect them. It becomes all at once too easy to decide you know best
column4: to never hear
column5: much less ignore
column6: protest to the contrary.

column2: many of those most in need of the sort of help liberals believe they can provide despise liberalism

column4: the ""help"" on offer drifts even further from the help these people need?

column1: It is impossible

column1: The smug style
column2: at bottom
column3: is a failure of empathy. Further: It is a failure to believe that empathy has any value at all. It is the notion that anybody worthy of liberal time and attention and respect must capitulate
column4: immediately
column5: to the Good Facts.

column1: If they don't (and they won't) you're free to write them off and mock them. When they suffer

column1: Make no mistake: I am not suggesting that liberals adopt a fuzzy
column2: gentler version of their politics. I am not suggesting they compromise their issues for the sake of playing nice. What I am suggesting is that the battles waged by liberalism have drifted far away from their old egalitarian intentions.

column1: I am suggesting that open disdain for the people they say they want to help has led them to stop helping those people
column2: too.

column1: I am suggesting that in the case of a Kim Davis
column2: liberalism resist the impulse to go beyond the necessary legal fight and explicitly delight in punishing an old foe.

column1: I am suggesting that they instead wonder what it might be like to have little left but one's values; to wake up one day to find your whole moral order destroyed; to look around and see the representatives of a new order call you a stupid
column2: hypocritical hick without bothering
column3: even
column4: to wonder how your corner of your poor state found itself so alienated from them in the first place. To work with people who do not share their values or their tastes
column5: who do not live where they live or like what they like or know their Good Facts or their jokes.

column1: This is not a call for civility. Manners are not enough. The smug style did not arise by accident
column2: and it cannot be abolished with a little self-reproach. So long as liberals cannot find common cause with the larger section of the American working class
column3: they will search for reasons to justify that failure. They will resent them. They will find

column1: Maybe the cycle is too deeply set already. Perhaps the divide
column2: the disdain
column3: the whole crack-up are inevitable. But if liberal good intentions are to make a play for a better future
column4: they cannot merely recognize the ways they've come to hate their former allies. They must begin to mend the ways they lost them in the first place."	0

column3: itÃÂs better than the alternative: rule by some authoritarian tyrant who tries to govern by clobbering everyone in his way.

column1: As Bernard Crick wrote in his book
column2: ÃÂIn Defence of Politics
column3: ÃÂ ÃÂPolitics is a way of ruling divided societies without undue violence.ÃÂ

column1: Over the past generation we have seen the rise of a group of people who are against politics. These groups ÃÂ best exemplified by the Tea Party but not exclusive to the right ÃÂ want to elect people who have no political experience. They want ÃÂoutsiders.ÃÂ They delegitimize compromise and deal-making. TheyÃÂre willing to trample the customs and rules that give legitimacy to legislative decision-making if it helps them gain power.
Ultimately
column2: they donÃÂt recognize other people. They suffer from a form of political narcissism
column3: in which they donÃÂt accept the legitimacy of other interests and opinions. They donÃÂt recognize restraints. They want total victories for themselves and their doctrine.

column1: This antipolitics tendency has had a wretched effect on our democracy. It has led to a series of overlapping downward spirals:
The antipolitics people elect legislators who have no political skills or experience. That incompetence leads to dysfunctional government
column2: which leads to more disgust with government
column3: which leads to a demand for even more outsiders.

column1: The antipolitics people donÃÂt accept that politics is a limited activity. They make soaring promises and raise ridiculous expectations. When those expectations are not met
column2: voters grow cynical and
column3: disgusted
column4: turn even further in the direction of antipolitics.

column1: The antipolitics people refuse compromise and so block the legislative process. The absence of accomplishment destroys public trust. The decline in trust makes deal-making harder.
WeÃÂre now at a point where the Senate says it wonÃÂt even hold hearings on a presidential Supreme Court nominee
column2: in clear defiance of custom and the Constitution. WeÃÂre now at a point in which politicians live in fear if they try to compromise and legislate. WeÃÂre now at a point in which normal political conversation has broken down. People feel unheard
column3: which makes them shout even louder
column4: which further destroys conversation.

column1: And in walks Donald Trump. People say that Trump is an unconventional candidate and that he represents a break from politics as usual. ThatÃÂs not true. Trump is the culmination of the trends we have been seeing for the last 30 years: the desire for outsiders; the bashing style of rhetoric that makes conversation impossible; the decline of coherent political parties; the declining importance of policy; the tendency to fight cultural battles and identity wars through political means.
Trump represents the path the founders rejected. There is a hint of violence undergirding his campaign. There is always a whiff
column2: and sometimes more than a whiff
column3: of ÃÂIÃÂd like to punch him in the face.ÃÂ

column1: I printed out a Times list of the insults Trump has hurled on Twitter. The list took up 33 pages. TrumpÃÂs style is bashing and pummeling. Everyone who opposes or disagrees with him is an idiot
column2: a moron or a loser. The implied promise of his campaign is that he will come to Washington and bully his way through.

column1: TrumpÃÂs supporters arenÃÂt looking for a political process to address their needs. They are looking for a superhero. As the political scientist Matthew MacWilliams found
column2: the one trait that best predicts whether youÃÂre a Trump supporter is how high you score on tests that measure authoritarianism.

column1: This isnÃÂt just an American phenomenon. Politics is in retreat and authoritarianism is on the rise worldwide. The answer to Trump is politics. ItÃÂs acknowledging other people exist. ItÃÂs taking pleasure in that difference and hammering out workable arrangements. As Harold Laski put it
column2: ÃÂWe shall make the basis of our state consent to disagreement. Therein shall we ensure its deepest harmony.ÃÂ"	0

column1: 184	"The American media
column2: over the past year
column3: has been trying to work out something of a mystery: Why is the Republican electorate supporting a far-right
column4: orange-toned populist with no real political experience
column5: who espouses extreme and often bizarre views? How has Donald Trump
column6: seemingly out of nowhere
column7: suddenly become so popular?

column1: What's made Trump's rise even more puzzling is that his support seems to cross demographic lines ÃÂ education
column2: income
column3: age
column4: even religiosity ÃÂ that usually demarcate candidates. And whereas most Republican candidates might draw strong support from just one segment of the party base
column5: such as Southern evangelicals or coastal moderates
