column7: and he won a resounding victory in the Nevada caucuses.

column1: Table of contents
I. What is American authoritarianism?
II. The discovery
III. How authoritarianism works
IV. What can authoritarianism explain?
V. The party of authoritarians
VI. Trump
column2: authoritarians
column3: and fear

column1: VII. America's changing social landscape
VIII. What authoritarians want
IX. How authoritarians will change American politics
Perhaps strangest of all
column2: it wasn't just Trump but his supporters who seemed to have come out of nowhere
column3: suddenly expressing
column4: in large numbers
column5: ideas far more extreme than anything that has risen to such popularity in recent memory. In South Carolina
column6: a CBS News exit poll found that 75 percent of Republican voters supported banning Muslims from the United States. A PPP poll found that a third of Trump voters support banning gays and lesbians from the country. Twenty percent said Lincoln shouldn't have freed the slaves.

column1: Last September
column2: a PhD student at the University of Massachusetts Amherst named Matthew MacWilliams realized that his dissertation research might hold the answer to not just one but all three of these mysteries.

column1: MacWilliams studies authoritarianism ÃÂ not actual dictators
column2: but rather a psychological profile of individual voters that is characterized by a desire for order and a fear of outsiders. People who score high in authoritarianism
column3: when they feel threatened
column4: look for strong leaders who promise to take whatever action necessary to protect them from outsiders and prevent the changes they fear.

column1: So MacWilliams naturally wondered if authoritarianism might correlate with support for Trump.
He polled a large sample of likely voters
column2: looking for correlations between support for Trump and views that align with authoritarianism. What he found was astonishing: Not only did authoritarianism correlate
column3: but it seemed to predict support for Trump more reliably than virtually any other indicator. He later repeated the same poll in South Carolina
column4: shortly before the primary there
column5: and found the same results
column6: which he published in Vox:

column1: As it turns out
column2: MacWilliams wasn't the only one to have this realization. Miles away
column3: in an office at Vanderbilt University
column4: a professor named Marc Hetherington was having his own aha moment. He realized that he and a fellow political scientist
column5: the University of North Carolina's Jonathan Weiler
column6: had essentially predicted Trump's rise back in 2009
column7: when they discovered something that would turn out to be far more significant than they then realized.

column1: That year
column2: Hetherington and Weiler published a book about the effects of authoritarianism on American politics. Through a series of experiments and careful data analysis
column3: they had come to a surprising conclusion: Much of the polarization dividing American politics was fueled not just by gerrymandering or money in politics or the other oft-cited variables
column4: but by an unnoticed but surprisingly large electoral group ÃÂ authoritarians.

column1: Their book concluded that the GOP
column2: by positioning itself as the party of traditional values and law and order
column3: had unknowingly attracted what would turn out to be a vast and previously bipartisan population of Americans with authoritarian tendencies.

column1: This trend had been accelerated in recent years by demographic and economic changes such as immigration
column2: which ""activated"" authoritarian tendencies
column3: leading many Americans to seek out a strongman leader who would preserve a status quo they feel is under threat and impose order on a world they perceive as increasingly alien.

column1: Trump embodies the classic authoritarian leadership style: simple
column2: powerful
column3: and punitive

column1: These Americans with authoritarian views
column2: they found
column3: were sorting into the GOP
column4: driving polarization. But they were also creating a divide within the party
column5: at first latent
column6: between traditional Republican voters and this group whose views were simultaneously less orthodox and
column7: often
column8: more extreme.

column1: Over time
column2: Hetherington and Weiler had predicted
column3: that sorting would become more and more pronounced. And so it was all but inevitable that
column4: eventually
column5: authoritarians would gain enough power within the GOP to make themselves heard.

column1: At the time
column2: even Hetherington and Weiler did not realize the explosive implications: that their theory
column3: when followed to its natural conclusion
column4: predicted a looming and dramatic transformation of American politics. But looking back now
column5: the ramifications of their research seem disturbingly clear.

column1: Authoritarians are thought to express much deeper fears than the rest of the electorate
column2: to seek the imposition of order where they perceive dangerous change
column3: and to desire a strong leader who will defeat those fears with force. They would thus seek a candidate who promised these things. And the extreme nature of authoritarians' fears
column4: and of their desire to challenge threats with force
column5: would lead them toward a candidate whose temperament was totally unlike anything we usually see in American politics ÃÂ and whose policies went far beyond the acceptable norms.

column1: A candidate like Donald Trump.
Donald Trump
(Scott Olson/Getty Images)
Even Hetherington was shocked to discover quite how right their theory had been. In the early fall of 2015
column2: as Trump's rise baffled most American journalists and political scientists
column3: he called Weiler. He asked
column4: over and over
column5: ""Can you believe this? Can you believe this?""

column1: This winter
column2: I got in touch with Hetherington
column3: MacWilliams
column4: and several other political scientists who study authoritarianism. I wanted to better understand the theory that seemed to have predicted
column5: with such eerie accuracy
column6: Trump's rise. And
column7: like them
column8: I wanted to find out what the rise of authoritarian politics meant for American politics. Was Trump just the start of something bigger?

column1: These political scientists were
column2: at that moment
column3: beginning to grapple with the same question. We agreed there was something important happening here ÃÂ that was just beginning to be understood.

column1: Donald Trump could be just the first of many Trumps in American politics
Shortly after the Iowa Republican caucus
column2: in which Trump came in a close second
column3: Vox partnered with the Washington-based media and polling company Morning Consult to test American authoritarians along a range of political and social views ÃÂ and to test some hypotheses we had developed after speaking with the leading political scientists of the field.

column1: What we found is a phenomenon that explains
column2: with remarkable clarity
column3: the rise of Donald Trump ÃÂ but that is also much larger than him
column4: shedding new light on some of the biggest political stories of the past decade. Trump
column5: it turns out
column6: is just the symptom. The rise of American authoritarianism is transforming the Republican Party and the dynamics of national politics
column7: with profound consequences likely to extend well beyond this election.

column1: I. What is American authoritarianism?
A Trump supporter carries a sign saying ""Build the wall""
Andrew Renneisen/Getty Images
For years now
column2: before anyone thought a person like Donald Trump could possibly lead a presidential primary
column3: a small but respected niche of academic research has been laboring over a question
column4: part political science and part psychology
column5: that had captivated political scientists since the rise of the Nazis.

column1: How do people come to adopt
column2: in such large numbers and so rapidly
column3: extreme political views that seem to coincide with fear of minorities and with the desire for a strongman leader?

column1: To answer that question
column2: these theorists study what they call authoritarianism: not the dictators themselves
column3: but rather the psychological profile of people who
column4: under the right conditions
column5: will desire certain kinds of extreme policies and will seek strongman leaders to implement them.

column1: The political phenomenon we identify as right-wing populism seems to line up
column2: with almost astonishing precision
column3: with the research on how authoritarianism is both caused and expressed

column1: After an early period of junk science in the mid-20th century
column2: a more serious group of scholars has addressed this question
column3: specifically studying how it plays out in American politics: researchers like Hetherington and Weiler
column4: Stanley Feldman
column5: Karen Stenner
column6: and Elizabeth Suhay
column7: to name just a few.

column1: The field
column2: after a breakthrough in the early 1990s
column3: has come to develop the contours of a grand theory of authoritarianism
column4: culminating quite recently
column6: with Stenner's seminal The Authoritarian Dynamic ÃÂ just in time for that theory to seemingly come true
column7: more rapidly and in greater force than any of them had imagined
column8: in the personage of one Donald Trump and his norm-shattering rise.

column1: According to Stenner's theory
column2: there is a certain subset of people who hold latent authoritarian tendencies. These tendencies can be triggered or ""activated"" by the perception of physical threats or by destabilizing social change
column3: leading those individuals to desire policies and leaders that we might more colloquially call authoritarian.

column1: It is as if
column2: the NYU professor Jonathan Haidt has written
column3: a button is pushed that says
column4: ""In case of moral threat
column5: lock down the borders
column6: kick out those who are different
column7: and punish those who are morally deviant.""

column1: Authoritarians are a real constituency that exists independently of Trump ÃÂ and will persist as a force in American politics
Authoritarians prioritize social order and hierarchies
column2: which bring a sense of control to a chaotic world. Challenges to that order ÃÂ diversity
column3: influx of outsiders
column4: breakdown of the old order ÃÂ are experienced as personally threatening because they risk upending the status quo order they equate with basic security.

column1: This is
column2: after all
column3: a time of social change in America. The country is becoming more diverse
column4: which means that many white Americans are confronting race in a way they have never had to before. Those changes have been happening for a long time
column5: but in recent years they have become more visible and harder to ignore. And they are coinciding with economic trends that have squeezed working-class white people.

column1: When they face physical threats or threats to the status quo
column2: authoritarians support policies that seem to offer protection against those fears. They favor forceful
column3: decisive action against things they perceive as threats. And they flock to political leaders who they believe will bring this action.

column1: If you were to read every word these theorists ever wrote on authoritarians
column2: and then try to design a hypothetical candidate to match their predictions of what would appeal to authoritarian voters
column3: the result would look a lot like Donald Trump.

column1: But political scientists say this theory explains much more than just Donald Trump
column2: placing him within larger trends in American politics: polarization
column3: the rightward shift of the Republican Party
column4: and the rise within that party of a dissident faction challenging GOP orthodoxies and upending American politics.

column1: More than that
column2: authoritarianism reveals the connections between several seemingly disparate stories about American politics. And it suggest that a combination of demographic
column3: economic
column4: and political forces
column5: by awakening this authoritarian class of voters that has coalesced around Trump
column6: have created what is essentially a new political party within the GOP ÃÂ a phenomenon that broke into public view with the 2016 election but will persist long after it has ended.

column1: II. The discovery: how a niche subfield of political science suddenly became some of the most relevant research in American politics
Buttons for sale on the day of the 2016 Iowa caucuses
Brendan Hoffman/Getty Images
Buttons for sale on the day of the 2016 Iowa caucuses.
This study of authoritarianism began shortly after World War II
column2: as political scientists and psychologists in the US and Europe tried to figure out how the Nazis had managed to win such wide public support for such an extreme and hateful ideology.

column1: That was a worthy field of study
column2: but the early work wasn't particularly rigorous by today's standards. The critical theorist Theodor Adorno
column3: for instance
column4: developed what he called the ""F-scale
column5: which sought to measure ""fascist"" tendencies. The test wasn't accurate. Sophisticated respondents would quickly discover what the ""right"" answers were and game the test. And there was no proof that the personality type it purportedly measured actually supported fascism.

column1: More than that
column2: this early research seemed to assume that a certain subset of people were inherently evil or dangerous ÃÂ an idea that Hetherington and Weiler say is simplistic and wrong
column3: and that they resist in their work. (They acknowledge the label ""authoritarians"" doesn't do much to dispel this
column4: but their efforts to replace it with a less pejorative-sounding term were unsuccessful.)

column1: If this rise in American authoritarianism is so powerful as to drive Trump's ascent
column2: then how else might it be shaping American politics?

column1: But the real problem for researchers was that even if there really were such a thing as an authoritarian psychological profile
column2: how do you measure it? How do you interrogate authoritarian tendencies
column3: which can sometimes be latent? How do you get honest answers on questions that can be sensitive and highly politicized?

column1: As Hetherington explained to me
column2: ""There are certain things that you just can't ask people directly. You can't ask people
column3: 'Do you not like black people?' You can't ask people if they're bigots.""

column1: For a long time
column2: no one had a solution for this
column3: and the field of study languished.

column1: Then in the early 1990s
column2: a political scientist named Stanley Feldman changed everything. Feldman
column3: a professor at SUNY Stonybrook
column4: believed authoritarianism could be an important factor in American politics in ways that had nothing to do with fascism
column5: but that it could only reliably be measured by unlinking it from specific political preferences.

column1: He realized that if authoritarianism were a personality profile rather than just a political preference
column2: he could get respondents to reveal these tendencies by asking questions about a topic that seemed much less controversial. He settled on something so banal it seems almost laughable: parenting goals.

column1: Feldman developed what has since become widely accepted as the definitive measurement of authoritarianism: four simple questions that appear to ask about parenting but are in fact designed to reveal how highly the respondent values hierarchy
column2: order
column3: and conformity over other values.

column1: Please tell me which one you think is more important for a child to have: independence or respect for elders?
Please tell me which one you think is more important for a child to have: obedience or self-reliance?
Please tell me which one you think is more important for a child to have: to be considerate or to be well-behaved?
Please tell me which one you think is more important for a child to have: curiosity or good manners?
Feldman's test proved to be very reliable. There was now a way to identify people who fit the authoritarian profile
column2: by prizing order and conformity
column3: for example
column4: and desiring the imposition of those values.

column2: Feldman convinced the National Election Study
column3: a large survey of American voters conducted in each national election year
column4: to include his four authoritarianism questions. Ever since
column5: political scientists who study authoritarianism have accumulated a wealth of data on who exhibits those tendencies and on how they align with everything from demographic profiles to policy preferences.

column1: What they found was impossible to ignore ÃÂ and is only just beginning to reshape our understanding of the American electorate.
III. How authoritarianism works
A Tea Party supporter holds a sign asking ""Obama where's your papers""
Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
A 2010 protest against President Obama.
In the early 2000s
column2: as researchers began to make use of the NES data to understand how authoritarianism affected US politics
column3: their work revealed three insights that help explain not just the rise of Trump
column4: but seemingly a half-century of American political dynamics.

column1: The first was Hetherington and Weiler's insight into partisan polarization. In the 1960s
column2: the Republican Party had reinvented itself as the party of law
column3: order
column4: and traditional values ÃÂ a position that naturally appealed to order- and tradition-focused authoritarians. Over the decades that followed
column5: authoritarians increasingly gravitated toward the GOP
column6: where their concentration gave them more and more influence over time.

column1: The second was Stenner's theory of ""activation."" In an influential 2005 book called The Authoritarian Dynamic
column2: Stenner argued that many authoritarians might be latent ÃÂ that they might not necessarily support authoritarian leaders or policies until their authoritarianism had been ""activated.""

column1: The social threat theory helps explain why authoritarians seem so prone to reject not just one specific kind of outsider or social change
column2: such as Muslims or same-sex couples or Hispanic migrants
column3: but rather to reject all of them

column1: This activation could come from feeling threatened by social changes such as evolving social norms or increasing diversity
column2: or any other change that they believe will profoundly alter the social order they want to protect. In response
column3: previously more moderate individuals would come to support leaders and policies we might now call Trump-esque.

column1: Other researchers
column2: like Hetherington
column3: take a slightly different view. They believe that authoritarians aren't ""activated"" ÃÂ they've always held their authoritarian preferences ÃÂ but that they only come to express those preferences once they feel threatened by social change or some kind of threat from outsiders.

column1: But both schools of thought agree on the basic causality of authoritarianism. People do not support extreme policies and strongman leaders just out of an affirmative desire for authoritarianism
column2: but rather as a response to experiencing certain kinds of threats.

column1: The third insight came from Hetherington and American University professor Elizabeth Suhay
column2: who found that when non-authoritarians feel sufficiently scared
column3: they also start to behave
column4: politically
column5: like authoritarians.

column1: But Hetherington and Suhay found a distinction between physical threats such as terrorism
column2: which could lead non-authoritarians to behave like authoritarians
column3: and more abstract social threats
column4: such as eroding social norms or demographic changes
column5: which do not have that effect. That distinction would turn out to be important
column6: but it also meant that in times when many Americans perceived imminent physical threats
column7: the population of authoritarians could seem to swell rapidly.

column1: Together
column2: those three insights added up to one terrifying theory: that if social change and physical threats coincided at the same time
column3: it could awaken a potentially enormous population of American authoritarians
column4: who would demand a strongman leader and the extreme policies necessary
column5: in their view
column6: to meet the rising threats.

column1: This theory would seem to predict the rise of an American political constituency that looks an awful lot like the support base that has emerged
column2: seemingly out of nowhere
column3: to propel Donald Trump from sideshow loser of the 2012 GOP primary to runaway frontrunner in 2016.

column1: Beyond being almost alarmingly prescient
column2: this theory speaks to an oft-stated concern about Trump: that what's scariest is not the candidate
column3: but rather the extent and fervor of his support.

column1: And it raises a question: If this rise in American authoritarianism is so powerful as to drive Trump's ascent
column2: then how else might it be shaping American politics? And what effect could it have even after the 2016 race has ended?

column1: IV. What can authoritarianism explain?
Trump greets supporters in Alabama
Mark Wallheiser/Getty Images
In early February
column2: shortly after Trump finished second in the Iowa caucus and ended any doubts about his support
column3: I began talking to Feldman
column4: Hetherington
column5: and MacWilliams to try to answer these questions.

column1: MacWilliams had already demonstrated a link between authoritarianism and support for Trump. But we wanted to know how else authoritarianism was playing out in American life
column2: from policy positions to party politics to social issues
column3: and what it might mean for America's future.

column1: It was time to call Kyle Dropp. Dropp is a political scientist and pollster whom one of my colleagues described as ""the Doogie Howser of polling."" He does indeed appear jarringly young for a Dartmouth professor. But he is also the co-founder of a media and polling company
column2: Morning Consult
column3: that had worked with Vox on several other projects.

column1: When we approached Morning Consult
column2: Dropp and his colleagues were excited. Dropp was familiar with Hetherington's work and the authoritarianism measure
column3: he said
column4: and was instantly intrigued by how we could test its relevance to the election. Hetherington and the other political scientists were
column5: in turn
column6: eager to more fully explore the theories that had suddenly become much more relevant.

column1: Non-authoritarians who were sufficiently frightened of threats like terrorism could essentially be scared into acting like authoritarians
We put together five sets of questions. The first set
column2: of course
column3: was the test for authoritarianism that Feldman had developed. This would allow us to measure how authoritarianism coincided or didn't with our other sets of questions.

column1: The second set asked standard election-season questions on preferred candidates and party affiliation.
The third set tested voters' fears of a series of physical threats
column2: ranging from ISIS and Russia to viruses and car accidents.

column1: The fourth set tested policy preferences
column2: in an attempt to see how authoritarianism might lead voters to support particular policies.

column1: If the research were right
column2: then we'd expect people who scored highly on authoritarianism to express outsize fear of ""outsider"" threats such as ISIS or foreign governments versus other threats. We also expected that non-authoritarians who expressed high levels of fear would be more likely to support Trump. This would speak to physical fears as triggering a kind of authoritarian upsurge
column3: which would in turn lead to Trump support.

column1: We wanted to look at the role authoritarians are playing in the election

The final set of questions was intended to test fear of social change. We asked people to rate a series of social changes ÃÂ both actual and hypothetical ÃÂ on a scale of ""very good"" to ""very bad"" for the country. These included same-sex marriage
column2: a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants living in the United States
column3: and American Muslims building more mosques in US cities.

column1: If the theory about social change provoking stress amongst authoritarians turned out to be correct
column2: then authoritarians would be more likely to rate the changes as bad for the country.

column1: In the aggregate
column2: we were hoping to do a few things. We wanted to understand who these people are
column3: in simple demographic terms
column4: and to test the basic hypotheses about how authoritarianism
column5: in theory
column6: is supposed to work. We wanted to look at the role authoritarians are playing in the election: Were they driving certain policy positions
column7: for example?

column1: We wanted to better understand the larger forces that had suddenly made authoritarians so numerous and so extreme ÃÂ was it migration
column2: terrorism
column3: perhaps the decline of working-class whites? And maybe most of all
column4: we wanted to develop some theories about what the rise of American authoritarianism meant for the future of polarization between the parties as well as a Republican Party that had become both more extreme and internally divided.

column1: About 10 days later
column2: shortly after Trump won the New Hampshire primary
column3: the poll went into the field. In less than two weeks
column4: we had our results.

column1: V. How the GOP became the party of authoritarians
Donald Trump and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie sign autographs during a Trump campaign event in Texas
Tom Pennington/Getty Images
Donald Trump and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie sign autographs during a Trump campaign event in Texas.

The first thing that jumped out from the data on authoritarians is just how many there are. Our results found that 44 percent of white respondents nationwide scored as ""high"" or ""very high"" authoritarians
column2: with 19 percent as ""very high."" That's actually not unusual
column3: and lines up with previous national surveys that found that the authoritarian disposition is far from rare1.

column1: The key thing to understand is that authoritarianism is often latent; people in this 44 percent only vote or otherwise act as authoritarians once triggered by some perceived threat
column2: physical or social. But that latency is part of how
column3: over the past few decades
column4: authoritarians have quietly become a powerful political constituency without anyone realizing it.

column1: Today
column2: according to our survey
column3: authoritarians skew heavily Republican. More than 65 percent of people who scored highest on the authoritarianism questions were GOP voters. More than 55 percent of surveyed Republicans scored as ""high"" or ""very high"" authoritarians.

column1: And at the other end of the scale
column2: that pattern reversed. People whose scores were most non-authoritarian ÃÂ meaning they always chose the non-authoritarian parenting answer ÃÂ were almost 75 percent Democrats.

column1: But this hasn't always been the case. According to Hetherington and Weiler's research
column2: this is not a story about how Republicans are from Mars and Democrats are from Venus. It's a story of polarization that increased over time.

column1: They trace the trend to the 1960s
column2: when the Republican Party shifted electoral strategies to try to win disaffected Southern Democrats
column3: in part by speaking to fears of changing social norms ÃÂ for example
column4: the racial hierarchies upset by civil rights. The GOP also embraced a ""law and order"" platform with a heavily racial appeal to white voters who were concerned about race riots.

column1: This positioned the GOP as the party of traditional values and social structures ÃÂ a role that it has maintained ever since. That promise to stave off social change and
column2: if necessary
column3: to impose order happened to speak powerfully to voters with authoritarian inclinations.

column1: Democrats
column2: by contrast
column3: have positioned themselves as the party of civil rights
column4: equality
column5: and social progress ÃÂ in other words
column6: as the party of social change
column7: a position that not only fails to attract but actively repels change-averse authoritarians.

column1: Over the next several decades
column2: Hetherington explained to me
column3: this led authoritarians to naturally ""sort"" themselves into the Republican Party.

column1: That matters
column2: because as more authoritarians sort themselves into the GOP
column3: they have more influence over its policies and candidates. It is not for nothing that our poll found that more than half of the Republican respondents score as authoritarian.

column1: Perhaps more importantly
column2: the party has less and less ability to ignore authoritarians' voting preferences ÃÂ even if those preferences clash with the mainstream party establishment.

column1: VI. Trump
column2: authoritarians
column3: and fear

column1: Based on our data
column2: Morning Consult data scientist Adam Petrihos said that ""among Republicans
column3: very high/high authoritarianism is very predictive of support for Trump."" Trump has 42 percent support among Republicans but
column4: according to our survey
column5: a full 52 percent support among very high authoritarians.

column1: Authoritarianism was the best single predictor of support for Trump
column2: although having a high school education also came close. And as Hetherington noted after reviewing our results
column3: the relationship between authoritarianism and Trump support remained robust
column4: even after controlling for education level and gender.

column1: Trump support was much lower among Republicans who scored low on authoritarianism: only 38 percent.
But that's still awfully high. So what could explain Trump's support among non-authoritarians?
I suspected the answer might lie at least partly in Hetherington and Suhay's research on how fear affects non-authoritarian voters
column2: so I called them to discuss the data. Hetherington crunched some numbers on physical threats and noticed two things.

column1: The first was that authoritarians tend to fear very specific kinds of physical threats.
Authoritarians
column2: we found in our survey
column3: tend to most fear threats that come from abroad
column4: such as ISIS or Russia or Iran. These are threats
column5: the researchers point out
column6: to which people can put a face; a scary terrorist or an Iranian ayatollah. Non-authoritarians were much less afraid of those threats. For instance
column7: 73 percent of very high-scoring authoritarians believed that terrorist organizations like ISIS posed a ""very high risk"" to them
column8: but only 45 percent of very low-scoring authoritarians did. Domestic threats like car accidents
column9: by contrast
column10: were much less frightening to authoritarians.

column1: But Hetherington also noticed something else: A subgroup of non-authoritarians were very afraid of threats like Iran or ISIS. And the more fear of these threats they expressed
column2: the more likely they were to support Trump.

column1: This seemed to confirm his and Suhay's theory: that non-authoritarians who are sufficiently frightened of physical threats such as terrorism could essentially be scared into acting like authoritarians.
That's important
column2: because for years now
column3: Republican politicians and Republican-leaning media such as Fox News have been telling viewers nonstop that the world is a terrifying place and that President Obama isn't doing enough to keep Americans safe.

column1: There are a variety of political and media incentives for why this happens. But the point is that
column2: as a result
column3: Republican voters have been continually exposed to messages warning of physical dangers. As the perception of physical threat has risen
column4: this fear appears to have led a number of non-authoritarians to vote like authoritarians ÃÂ to support Trump.

column1: An irony of this primary is that the Republican establishment has tried to stop Trump by
column2: among other things
column3: co-opting his message. But when establishment candidates such as Marco Rubio try to match Trump's rhetoric on ISIS or on American Muslims
column4: they may end up deepening the fear that can only lead voters back to Trump.

column1: VII. Is America's changing social landscape ""activating"" authoritarianism?
But the research on authoritarianism suggests it's not just physical threats driving all this. There should be another kind of threat ÃÂ larger
column2: slower
column3: less obvious
column4: but potentially even more powerful ÃÂ pushing authoritarians to these extremes: the threat of social change.

column1: This could come in the form of evolving social norms
column2: such as the erosion of traditional gender roles or evolving standards in how to discuss sexual orientation. It could come in the form of rising diversity
column3: whether that means demographic changes from immigration or merely changes in the colors of the faces on TV. Or it could be any changes
column4: political or economic
column5: that disrupt social hierarchies.

column1: What these changes have in common is that
column2: to authoritarians
column3: they threaten to take away the status quo as they know it ÃÂ familiar
column4: orderly
column5: secure ÃÂ and replace it with something that feels scary because it is different and destabilizing
column6: but also sometimes because it upends their own place in society. According to the literature
column7: authoritarians will seek
column8: in response
column9: a strong leader who promises to suppress the scary changes
column10: if necessary by force
column11: and to preserve the status quo.

column1: This is why
column2: in our survey
column3: we wanted to study the degree to which authoritarians versus non-authoritarians expressed a fear of social change ÃÂ and whether this
column4: as expected
column5: led them to desire heavy-handed responses.

column1: Our results seemed to confirm this: Authoritarians were significantly more likely to rate almost all of the actual and hypothetical social issues we asked about as ""bad"" or ""very bad"" for the country.
For instance
column2: our results suggested that an astonishing 44 percent of authoritarians believe same-sex marriage is harmful to the country. Twenty-eight percent rated same-sex marriage as ""very bad"" for America
column3: and another 16 percent said that itÃÂs ""bad."" Only about 35 percent of high-scoring authoritarians said same-sex marriage was ""good"" or ""very good"" for the country.

column1: Tellingly
column2: non-authoritarians' responses skewed in the opposite direction. Non-authoritarians tended to rate same-sex marriage as ""good"" or ""very good"" for the country.

column1: The fact that authoritarians and non-authoritarians split over something as seemingly personal and nonthreatening as same-sex marriage is crucial for understanding how authoritarianism can be triggered by even a social change as minor as expanding marriage rights.

We also asked respondents to rate whether Muslims building more mosques in American cities was a good thing. This was intended to test respondents' comfort level with sharing their communities with Muslims ÃÂ an issue that has been particularly contentious this primary election.

A whopping 56.5 percent of very high-scoring authoritarians said it was either ""bad"" or ""very bad"" for the country when Muslims built more mosques. Only 14 percent of that group said more mosques would be ""good"" or ""very good.""
The literature on authoritarianism suggests this is not just simple Islamophobia
column2: but rather reflects a broader phenomenon wherein authoritarians feel threatened by people they identify as ""outsiders"" and by the possibility of changes to the status quo makeup of their communities.

column1: This would help explain why authoritarians seem so prone to reject not just one specific kind of outsider or social change
column2: such as Muslims or same-sex couples or Hispanic migrants
column3: but rather to reject all of them. What these seemingly disparate groups have in common is the perceived threat they pose to the status quo order
column4: which authoritarians experience as a threat to themselves.

column1: And America is at a point when the status quo social order is changing rapidly; when several social changes are converging. And they are converging especially on working-class white people.
It is conventional wisdom to ascribe the rise of first the Tea Party right and now Trump to the notion that working-class white Americans are angry.
Indeed they are
column2: but this data helps explain that they are also under certain demographic and economic pressures that
column3: according to this research
column4: are highly likely to trigger authoritarianism ÃÂ and thus suggests there is something a little more complex going on than simple ""anger"" that helps explain their gravitation toward extreme political responses.

column1: Working-class communities have come under tremendous economic strain since the recession. And white people are also facing the loss of the privileged position that they previously were able to take for granted. Whites are now projected to become a minority group over the next few decades
column2: owing to migration and other factors. The president is a black man
column3: and nonwhite faces are growing more common in popular culture. Nonwhite groups are raising increasingly prominent political demands
column4: and often those demands coincide with issues such as policing that also speak to authoritarian concerns.

column1: Some of these factors might be considered more or less legitimately threatening than others ÃÂ the loss of working-class jobs in this country is a real and important issue
column2: no matter how one feels about fading white privilege ÃÂ but that is not the point.

column1: The point
column2: rather
column3: is that the increasingly important political phenomenon we identify as right-wing populism
column4: or white working-class populism
column5: seems to line up
column6: with almost astonishing precision
column7: with the research on how authoritarianism is both caused and expressed.

column1: That is not to dismiss white working-class concerns as invalid because they might be expressed by authoritarians or through authoritarian politics
column2: but rather to better understand why this is happening ÃÂ and why it's having such a profound and extreme effect on American politics.

column1: Have we misunderstood hard-line social conservatism all along?
Most of the other social-threat questions followed a similar pattern2. On its surface
column2: this might seem to suggest that authoritarianism is just a proxy for especially hard-line manifestations of social conservatism. But when examined more carefully
column3: it suggests something more interesting about the nature of social conservatism itself.

column1: For liberals
column2: it may be easy to conclude that opposition to things like same-sex marriage
column3: immigration
column4: and diversity is rooted in bigotry against those groups ÃÂ that it's the manifestation of specific homophobia
column5: xenophobia
column6: and Islamophobia.

column1: But the results of the Vox/Morning Consult poll
column2: along with prior research on authoritarianism
column3: suggests there might be something else going on.

column1: There is no particular reason
column2: after all
column3: why parenting goals should coincide with animus against specific groups. We weren't asking questions about whether it was important for children to respect people of different races
column4: but about whether they should respect authority and rules generally. So why do they coincide so heavily?

column1: What might look on the surface like bigotry was really much closer to Stenner's theory of ""activation""
What is most likely
column2: Hetherington suggested
column3: is that authoritarians are much more susceptible to messages that tell them to fear a specific ""other"" ÃÂ whether or not they have a preexisting animus against that group. Those fears would therefore change over time as events made different groups seem more or less threatening.

column1: It all depends
column2: he said
column3: on whether a particular group of people has been made into an outgroup or not ÃÂ whether they had been identified as a dangerous other.

column1: Since September 2001
column2: some media outlets and politicians have painted Muslims as the other and as dangerous to America. Authoritarians
column3: by nature
column4: are more susceptible to these messages
column5: and thus more likely to come to oppose the presence of mosques in their communities.

column1: When told to fear a particular outgroup
column2: Hetherington said
column3: ""On average people who score low in authoritarianism will be like
column4: 'IÃÂm not that worried about that
column5: ' while people who score high in authoritarianism will be like
column6: 'Oh
column7: my god! IÃÂm worried about that
column8: because the world is a dangerous place.'""

column1: In other words
column2: what might look on the surface like bigotry was really much closer to Stenner's theory of ""activation"": that authoritarians are unusually susceptible to messages about the ways outsiders and social changes threaten America
column3: and so lash out at groups that are identified as objects of concern at that given moment.

column1: That's not to say that such an attitude is in some way better than simple racism or xenophobia ÃÂ it is still dangerous and damaging
column2: especially if it empowers frightening demagogues like Donald Trump.

column1: Perhaps more to the point
column2: it helps explain how Trump's supporters have come to so quickly embrace such extreme policies targeting these outgroups: mass deportation of millions of people
column3: a ban on foreign Muslims visiting the US. When you think about those policy preferences as driven by authoritarianism
column4: in which social threats are perceived as especially dangerous and as demanding extreme responses
column5: rather than the sudden emergence of specific bigotries
column6: this starts to make a lot more sense.

column1: VIII. What authoritarians want
From our parenting questions
column2: we learned who the GOP authoritarians are. From our questions about threats and social change
column3: we learned what's motivating them. But the final set of questions
column4: on policy preferences
column5: might be the most important of all: So what? What do authoritarians actually want?

column1: The responses to our policy questions showed that authoritarians have their own set of policy preferences
column2: distinct from GOP orthodoxy. And those preferences mean that
column3: in real and important ways
column4: authoritarians are their own distinct constituency: effectively a new political party within the GOP.

column1: What stands out from the results
column2: Feldman wrote after reviewing our data
column3: is that authoritarians ""are most willing to want to use force
column4: to crack down on immigration
column5: and limit civil liberties.""

column1: This ""action side"" of authoritarianism
column2: he believed
column3: was the key thing that distinguished Trump supporters from supporters of other GOP candidates. ""The willingness to use government power to eliminate the threats ÃÂ that is most clear among Trump supporters.""

column1: Authoritarians generally and Trump voters specifically
column2: we found
column3: were highly likely to support five policies:

column1: Using military force over diplomacy against countries that threaten the United States
Changing the Constitution to bar citizenship for children of illegal immigrants
Imposing extra airport checks on passengers who appear to be of Middle Eastern descent in order to curb terrorism
Requiring all citizens to carry a national ID card at all times to show to a police officer on request
column2: to curb terrorism

column1: Allowing the federal government to scan all phone calls for calls to any number linked to terrorism
What these policies share in common is an outsize fear of threats
column2: physical and social
column3: and
column4: more than that
column5: a desire to meet those threats with severe government action ÃÂ with policies that are authoritarian not just in style but in actuality. The scale of the desired response is
column6: in some ways
column7: what most distinguishes authoritarians from the rest of the GOP.

column1: Many Republicans seem to be threatened by terrorism
column2: violence
column3: and cultural diversity
column4: but that's not unique to Trump supporters
column5: Feldman told me.

column1: It seems to be the action side of authoritarianism ÃÂ the willingness to use government power to eliminate the threats ÃÂ that is most clear among Trump supporters
column2: he added.

column1: If Trump loses the election
column2: that won't remove the threats and social changes that trigger the ""action side"" of authoritarianism

column1: This helps explain why the GOP has had such a hard time co-opting Trump's supporters
column2: even though those supporters' immediate policy concerns
column3: such as limiting immigration or protecting national security
column4: line up with party orthodoxy. The real divide is over how far to go in responding. And the party establishment is simply unwilling to call for such explicitly authoritarian policies.

column1: Just as striking is what was missing from authoritarians' concerns. There was no clear correlation between authoritarianism and support for tax cuts for people making more than $250
column2: 000 per year
column3: for example. And the same was true of support for international trade agreements.

column1: These are both issues associated with mainstream GOP economic policies. All groups opposed the tax cuts
column2: and support for trade agreements was evenly lukewarm across all degrees of authoritarianism. So there is no real divide on these issues.

column1: But there is one more factor that our data couldn't capture but is nevertheless important: Trump's style.
Trump's specific policies aren't the thing that most sets him apart from the rest of the field of GOP candidates. Rather
column2: it's his rhetoric and style. The way he reduces everything to black-and-white extremes of strong versus weak
column3: greatest versus worst. His simple
column4: direct promises that he can solve problems that other politicians are too weak to manage.

column1: And
column2: perhaps most importantly
column3: his willingness to flout all the conventions of civilized discourse when it comes to the minority groups that authoritarians find so threatening. That's why it's a benefit rather than a liability for Trump when he says Mexicans are rapists or speaks gleefully of massacring Muslims with pig-blood-tainted bullets: He is sending a signal to his authoritarian supporters that he won't let ""political correctness"" hold him back from attacking the outgroups they fear.

column1: This
column2: Feldman explained to me
column3: is ""classic authoritarian leadership style: simple
column4: powerful
column5: and punitive.""

column1: IX. How authoritarians will change the GOP ÃÂ and American politics
Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz confront Trump during the February 25 GOP debate
Michael Ciaglo/Pool/Getty Images
To my surprise
column2: the most compelling conclusion to come out of our polling data wasn't about Trump at all.

column1: Rather
column2: it was that authoritarians
column3: as a growing presence in the GOP
column4: are a real constituency that exists independently of Trump ÃÂ and will persist as a force in American politics regardless of the fate of his candidacy.

column1: If Trump loses the election
column2: that will not remove the threats and social changes that trigger the ""action side"" of authoritarianism. The authoritarians will still be there. They will still look for candidates who will give them the strong
column3: punitive leadership they desire.

column1: And that means Donald Trump could be just the first of many Trumps in American politics
column2: with potentially profound implications for the country.

column1: It would also mean more problems for the GOP. This election is already showing that the party establishment abhors Trump and all he stands for ÃÂ his showy demagoguery
column2: his disregard for core conservative economic values
column3: his divisiveness.

column1: We may now have a de facto three-party system: the Democrats
column2: the GOP establishment
column3: and the GOP authoritarians

column1: But while the party may try to match Trump's authoritarian rhetoric
column2: and its candidates may grudgingly embrace some of his harsher policies toward immigrants or Muslims
column3: in the end a mainstream political party cannot fully commit to extreme authoritarian action the way Trump can.

column1: That will be a problem for the party. Just look at where the Tea Party has left the Republican establishment. The Tea Party delivered the House to the GOP in 2010
column2: but ultimately left the party in an unresolved civil war. Tea Party candidates have challenged moderates and centrists
column3: leaving the GOP caucus divided and chaotic.

column1: Now a similar divide is playing out at the presidential level
column2: with results that are even more destructive for the Republican Party. Authoritarians may be a slight majority within the GOP
column3: and thus able to force their will within the party
column4: but they are too few and their views too unpopular to win a national election on their own.

column1: And so the rise of authoritarianism as a force within American politics means we may now have a de facto three-party system: the Democrats
column2: the GOP establishment
column3: and the GOP authoritarians.

column1: And although the latter two groups are presently forced into an awkward coalition
column2: the GOP establishment has demonstrated a complete inability to regain control over the renegade authoritarians
column3: and the authoritarians are actively opposed to the establishment's centrist goals and uninterested in its economic platform.

column1: Over time
column2: this will have significant political consequences for the Republican Party. It will become more difficult for Republican candidates to win the presidency because the candidates who can win the nomination by appealing to authoritarian primary voters will struggle to court mainstream voters in the general election. They will have less trouble with local and congressional elections
column3: but that might just mean more legislative gridlock as the GOP caucus struggles to balance the demands of authoritarian and mainstream legislators. The authoritarian base will drag the party further to the right on social issues
column4: and will simultaneously erode support for traditionally conservative economic policies.

column1: And in the meantime
column2: the forces activating American authoritarians seem likely to only grow stronger. Norms around gender
column3: sexuality
column4: and race will continue evolving. Movements like Black Lives Matter will continue chipping away at the country's legacy of institutionalized discrimination
column5: pursuing the kind of social change and reordering of society that authoritarians find so threatening.

column1: The chaos in the Middle East
column2: which allows groups like ISIS to flourish and sends millions of refugees spilling into other countries
column3: shows no sign of improving. Longer term
column4: if current demographic trends continue
column5: white Americans will cease to be a majority over the coming decades.

column1: In the long run
column2: this could mean a GOP that is even more hard-line on immigration and on policing
column3: that is more outspoken about fearing Muslims and other minority groups
column4: but also takes a softer line on traditional party economic issues like tax cuts. It will be a GOP that continues to perform well in congressional and local elections
column5: but whose divisions leave the party caucus divided to the point of barely functioning
column6: and perhaps eventually unable to win the White House.

column1: For decades
column2: the Republican Party has been winning over authoritarians by implicitly promising to stand firm against the tide of social change
column3: and to be the party of force and power rather than the party of negotiation and compromise. But now it may be discovering that its strategy has worked too well ÃÂ and threatens to tear the party apart."	0

194	"As debate about ObamacareÃÂs future moves from peopleÃÂs general
column2: mostly partisan views of the Affordable Care Act to details and consequences of plans to repeal and replace the ACA
column3: one of the biggest flash points is likely to be how people with pre-existing medical conditions are affected.

column1: Across the U.S.
column2: people who have cancer
column3: heart disease
column4: diabetes
column5: or other serious conditions will want to know whether they or their sick family members will be able to get and afford coverage in the future. Their partisan views about Obamacare are likely to quickly be supplanted by these more practical concerns. And a substantial number of people could be affected.

column1: A Kaiser Family Foundation analysis to be released next week found that almost 30% of U.S. adults younger than 65 have health conditions that would have left them uninsurable in a pre-ACA world. Many more people have conditions with which they could still qualify for coverage before ACA protections took effectÃÂbut only at premiums they could not afford. Many people with conditions over which coverage could be declined before the ACA live in big red states (there are more than 4 million in Texas
column2: for example) and in blue states (nearly 6 million in California). As the chart above shows
column3: however
column4: the 11 states with the largest shares of adults who have pre-existing conditions are all controlled by Republicans
column5: and most are in the South. These states have higher rates of residents with conditions over which coverage was declined before the ACA
column6: such as obesity and diabetes.

column1: Still
column2: even more Americans may feel that they have a stake in policies regarding pre-existing conditions. KaiserÃÂs monthly health tracking poll found in August that 53% of Americans said that they or a family member had a pre-existing condition after being read a definition of the term. Most people with pre-existing conditions are insured at any given time through employer plans or public programs such as Medicaid. Before the ACA
column3: however
column4: they would have been unable to get coverage again if they lost their insurance through a change in circumstances. Because so many people with a pre-existing condition have to worry about whether their circumstances might change someday
column5: a much larger share of the public is likely to be interested in this issue than the number of people who stand to be affected immediately by policy changes.

column1: President-elect Donald Trump has said that he wants to protect people who have pre-existing medical conditions. Details of Republican health-care plans are not yet known
column2: but they are expected to involve establishing high-risk pools within states
column3: among other measures. Without the plan details it is hard to say how strong protections will be.

column1: Tens of millions of people with pre-existing medical conditions and the influential groups that represent them will be interested in details of legislative plans to change the ACA and how they might be affected. ItÃÂs sometimes said that this has become a post-factual world. But as health care moves from a campaign issue to the legislative agenda
column2: people will want to know how changes would affect them
column3: and details and facts will matter more again.

column1: Donald Trump Campaigns Across New Hampshire Ahead Of Primary Day

Trump is in serious contention to win the Republican presidential nomination. His triumph in a general election is unlikely
column2: but it is far from impossible. He's not a joke and he's not a clown. He's a man who could soon be making decisions of war and peace
column3: who would decide which regulations are enforced and which are lifted

column1: Trump's path to power has been unnerving. His business is licensing out his own name as a symbol of opulence. He has endured bankruptcies and scandal by bragging his way out of them. He rose to prominence in the Republican Party as a leader of the birther movement. He climbed to the top of the polls in this election by calling Mexicans rapists and killers. column2: all these illegals need to be deported

column5: he said in his New Hampshire victory speech

column7: Japan

column4: 'IÃÂM angry.'"" Trump doesn't offer solutions so much as he offers villains. His message isn't so much that he'll help you as he'll hurt them.

column1: Donald Trump Holds New Hampshire Primary Night Gathering In Manchester
Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images

Trump's other gift ÃÂ the one that gets less attention but is perhaps more important ÃÂ is his complete lack of shame. It's easy to underestimate how important shame is in American politics. But shame is our most powerful restraint on politicians who would find success through demagoguery. Most people feel shame when they're exposed as liars
column2: when they're seen as uninformed
column3: when their behavior is thought cruel
column4: when respected figures in their party condemn their actions
column5: when experts dismiss their proposals
column6: when they are mocked and booed and protested.

column1: Trump doesn't. He has the reality television star's ability to operate entirely without shame
column2: and that permits him to operate entirely without restraint. It is the single scariest facet of his personality. It is the one that allows him to go where others won't
column3: to say what others can't
column4: to do what others wouldn't.

column1: Trump lives by the reality television trope that he's not here to make friends. But the reason reality television villains always say they're not there to make friends is because it sets them apart
column2: makes them unpredictable and fun to watch. ""I'm not here to make friends"" is another way of saying
column3: ""I'm not bound by the social conventions of normal people."" The rest of us are here to make friends
column4: and it makes us boring
column5: gentle
column6: kind.

column1: This
column2: more than his ideology
column3: is why Trump genuinely scares me. There are places where I think his instincts are an improvement on the Republican field. He seems more dovish than neoconservatives like Marco Rubio
column4: and less dismissive of the social safety net than libertarians like Rand Paul. But those candidates are checked by institutions and incentives that hold no sway over Trump; his temperament is so immature
column5: his narcissism so clear
column6: his political base so unique
column7: his reactions so strange
column8: that I honestly have no idea what he would do ÃÂ or what he wouldn't do.

column8: he clarified that he doesn't actually condone killing journalists
column9: but
column10: he warned the crowd
column11: ""I do hate them.""

column1: 221	"Like many foreign scientists in Britain

column1: Britain's top universities have long been among the world's most sought-after destinations for study and research
column2: drawing the brightest minds from all corners of the globe. But since Britons voted in June to leave the 28-nation EU
column3: many in the science community say the U.K. risks losing the money
column4: the international influence ÃÂ and crucially
column5: the talent ÃÂ to sustain that enviable position.

column1: More than one-tenth of research funding at British universities has come from the EU in recent years. Some fields ÃÂ such as nanotechnology and cancer research ÃÂ are more dependent on EU funding than others
column2: according to a report by technology firm Digital Science. From 2007 to 2013
column3: Britain received 8.8 billion euros ($9.4 billion) in direct EU investment in research.

column1: Bagniewska is not just anxious about herself ÃÂ she's upset for her students' future too
column2: for the opportunities that both Britons and foreigners will likely miss out on when unfettered mobility between Britain and Europe can no longer be taken for granted.

column1: They were just getting excited about doing their masters and Ph.Ds in other countries. And then Brexit happened and they just got trampled

column1: Scientists and researchers argue that being part of the EU has given British science a huge boost because it allows Britain to recruit the best talent across Europe and take part in important research collaborations and student exchanges without being constrained by national boundaries. The bloc's freedom of movement means its 500 million people can live and work visa-free in any member state.
No one knows yet what form Britain's exit from the EU ÃÂ commonly known as Brexit ÃÂ is going to take
column2: but immigration was a key issue for ""Leave"" voters. Many believe some limit should be put on the number of EU citizens moving to Britain.

column1: Prime Minister Theresa May has vowed to reassert control over British borders. She has offered no firm guarantees for the rights of Europeans already living in Britain
column2: an uncertainty that weighs heavily over the 32
column3: 000 Europeans who make up 16 percent of the academic workforce in British universities. Many universities say the rhetoric over immigration control is also jeopardizing recruitment of researchers and students from further afield.

column1: Scientists for EU
column2: an advocacy group
column3: says it has received over 400 letters from researchers describing how Brexit has already impacted their life and work. Some are losing doctoral students who pulled out of studentships and job offers. Academics are putting plans to relocate to Britain on hold. One said their employer
column4: a London university
column5: immediately imposed a temporary hiring freeze
column6: citing uncertainties about student recruitment and research income.

column1: Adam Durrant
column2: a British entrepreneur who founded an aerospace startup supplying climate data to airlines and aircraft manufacturers
column3: says he's now considering moving some of his business to a EU country outside of Britain. Part of the reason
column4: he says

column1: In the future
column2: it probably means that people would be less interested to come to the U.K. to work

column4: but my company's focus of gravity may shift elsewhere.""

Paul Crowther
column2: head of physics and astronomy at the University of Sheffield
column3: said a researcher from his department was dropped from an EU grant proposal as a precaution following the Brexit referendum. The vote ""put the U.K.-based researchers in a very awkward position"" and their participation in EU-funded programs could ""compromise the project
column4: he was told.

column1: The erosion of U.K. involvement in EU networks has already begun

column1: Apart from a loss of grant money
column2: Brexit will likely cause British scientists and research centers to miss out on shared databases and infrastructure.

column1: Large-scale efforts like studies of rare genetic diseases

column3: are areas that multinational collaborations do much better

column5: a Nobel Prize-winning biologist and president of Britain's prestigious Royal Society.

column1: The EU is an important source of research funding for Britain
column2: which lags behind many developed countries in state investment in science. In 2014
column3: Britain's government spent under 0.5 percent of its GDP on research ÃÂ below the European average
column4: and half that of South Korea.

column1: May's government is clearly aware of the jitters. She has promised to increase annual investment in research by 2 billion pounds ($2.4 billion) by 2020
column2: in hopes her country can remain a world leader in science and innovation.

column1: Durrant is doubtful that's enough to make a big difference.
Two billion a year spread across everything isn't going to go very far
column2: he said.

column1: Similar anxieties are being felt at the undergraduate level. The 125
column2: 000 European students studying at British universities now pay the same fees as locals and have access to the same government loans. Officials have promised this will not change for those applying next year ÃÂ but no one knows what will happen after that.

column1: Fewer European students appeared to be applying for some of Britain's most competitive university courses
column2: including medicine and places at Oxford and Cambridge. In September
column3: the admission service UCAS reported a 9 percent drop in EU applications for British undergraduate courses starting in 2017.

column1: Some argue that Britain could become like Switzerland
column2: an ""associate"" EU state that is opting out of free movement of people while still taking part in limited European science projects.

column1: It's not all doom and gloom ÃÂ but it will be harder

column3: we have to attract talent and fund science. And those two things are critical."""	0

column3: the Republican coalition has inherited the people who opposed the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ÃÂ the Southern Democrats who are now Republicans
column4: ÃÂ Roy says. ÃÂConservatives and Republicans have not come to terms with that problem.ÃÂ

column1: Conservative intellectuals were blind to the truth about the GOP ÃÂ hence Trump
Avik Roy (L) discusses Obamacare on television. (William B. Plowman/NBC/NBC News/Getty Images)
The available evidence compiled by historians and political scientists suggests that 1964 really was a pivotal political moment
column2: in exactly the way Roy describes.

column1: Yet Republican intellectuals have long denied this
column2: fabricating a revisionist history in which Republicans were and always have been the party of civil rights. In 2012
column3: National Review ran a lengthy cover story arguing that the standard history recounted by Roy was ÃÂpopular but indefensible.ÃÂ

column1: This revisionism
column2: according to Roy
column3: points to a much bigger conservative delusion: They cannot admit that their partyÃÂs voters are motivated far more by white identity politics than by conservative ideals.

column1: ÃÂConservative intellectuals
column2: and conservative politicians
column3: have been in kind of a bubble
column4: ÃÂ Roy says. ÃÂWeÃÂve had this view that the voters were with us on conservatism ÃÂ philosophical
column5: economic conservatism. In reality
column6: the gravitational center of the Republican Party is white nationalism.ÃÂ

column1: Conservative intellectuals
column2: for the most part
column3: are horrified by racism. When they talk about believing in individual rights and equality
column4: they really mean it. Because the Republican Party is the vehicle through which their ideas can be implemented
column5: they need to believe that the party isnÃÂt racist.

column1: So they deny the partyÃÂs racist history
column2: that its post-1964 success was a direct result of attracting whites disillusioned by the DemocratsÃÂ embrace of civil rights. And they deny that to this day
column3: Republican voters are driven more by white resentment than by a principled commitment to the free market and individual liberty.

column1: ÃÂItÃÂs the power of wishful thinking. None of us want to accept that opposition to civil rights is the legacy that weÃÂve inherited
column2: ÃÂ Roy says.

column1: He expands on this idea: ÃÂItÃÂs a common observation on the left
column2: but itÃÂs an observation that a lot of us on the right genuinely believed wasnÃÂt true ÃÂ which is that conservatism has become
column3: and has been for some time
column4: much more about white identity politics than it has been about conservative political philosophy. I think today
column5: even now
column6: a lot of conservatives have not come to terms with that problem.ÃÂ

column1: This
column2: Roy believes
column3: is where the conservative intellectual class went astray. By refusing to admit the truth about their own party
column4: they were powerless to stop the forces that led to Donald TrumpÃÂs rise. They told themselves
column5: over and over again
column6: that GoldwaterÃÂs victory was a triumph.

column1: But in reality
column2: it created the conditions under which Trump could thrive. TrumpÃÂs politics of aggrieved white nationalism ÃÂ labeling black people criminals
column3: Latinos rapists
column4: and Muslims terrorists ÃÂ succeeded because the partyÃÂs voting base was made up of the people who once opposed civil rights.

column1: ÃÂ[Trump] tapped into something that was latent in the Republican Party and conservative movement ÃÂ but a lot of people in the conservative movement didnÃÂt notice
column2: ÃÂ Roy concludes
column3: glumly.

column1: For conservatism to live
column2: the conservative movement has to die

column1: A sign with one of the RNCÃÂs most popular slogans. (Bill Clark/CQ Roll Cal)
Over beers
column2: I ask Roy how he feels about all of this personally. His answer is very sad.

column1: ÃÂWhen Marco [Rubio] lost
column2: I went through the five stages of grief. It was tough. I had to spend some time thinking about what to do for the next several years of my life
column3: ÃÂ he says.

column1: ÃÂI left a comforting and rewarding career as a biotech investor to do this kind of work. I did it because I felt it was important
column2: and I care about the country. Maybe itÃÂs cheesy to say that
column3: but I really sincerely do
column4: ÃÂ he continues. ÃÂSo then
column5: okay
column6: what do I do? Do I do the same things IÃÂve been doing for the last four years? To me
column7: just to do that to collect a paycheck didnÃÂt make a lot of sense.ÃÂ

column1: This soul-searching led Roy to an uncomfortable conclusion: The Republican Party
column2: and the conservative movement that propped it up
column3: is doomed.

column1: Both are too wedded to the politics of white nationalism to change how they act
column2: but that just isnÃÂt a winning formula in a nation thatÃÂs increasingly black and brown. Either the Republican Party will eat itself or a new party will rise and overtake its voting share.

column1: ÃÂEither the disruption will come from the Republican Party representing cranky old white people and a new right-of-center party emerging in its place
column2: or a third party will emerge
column3: ÃÂ  la the Republicans emerging from the Whigs in the [1850s]
column4: ÃÂ Roy says.

column1: The work of conservative intellectuals today
column2: he argues
column3: is to devise a new conservatism ÃÂ a political vision that adheres to limited government principles but genuinely appeals to a more diverse America.

column1: ÃÂI think itÃÂs incredibly important to take stock
column2: ÃÂ he says
column3: ÃÂand build a new conservative movement that is genuinely about individual liberty.ÃÂ

column1: I donÃÂt know how this would work. I donÃÂt think Roy knows either.
For the entire history of modern conservatism
column2: its ideals have been wedded to and marred by white supremacism. ThatÃÂs RoyÃÂs own diagnosis
column3: and I think itÃÂs correct. As a result
column4: we have literally no experience in America of a politically viable conservative movement unmoored from white supremacy.

column1: IÃÂve read dozens of conservative intellectuals writing compellingly about non-racist conservative ideals. Writers like Andrew Sullivan
column2: Ross Douthat
column3: Reihan Salam
column4: Michael Brendan Dougherty
column5: and too many others to count have put forward visions of a conservative party quite different from the one we have.

column1: But not one of these writers
column2: smart as they are
column3: has been able to explain what actual political constituency could bring about this pure conservatism in practice. The fact is that limited government conservatism is not especially appealing to nonwhite Americans
column4: whereas liberalism and social democracy are. The only ones for whom conservatism is a natural fit are RoyÃÂs ÃÂcranky old white peopleÃÂ ÃÂ and theyÃÂre dying off.

column1: Maybe Roy and company will be able to solve this problem. I hope they do. America needs a viable
column2: intellectually serious right-of-center party.

column1: Because we now know what the alternative looks like. ItÃÂs Donald Trump.
