column1: 253	"Tired and frustrated after spending so much time dealing with a bitterly divided Congress that needlessly created self-inflicted wounds to the U.S. economy
column2: President Obama has begun to privately weigh the personal benefits of losing the 2012 presidential election. However
column3: as the Republican field takes form
column4: he is increasingly concerned that the number of weak candidates could force him to remain in the nationÃÂs worst job whether he wants to or not.

column1: One of the more difficult challenges for Obama would be losing to Texas Governor Rick Perry
column2: who is currently considered co-frontrunner for the nomination. With a slew of controversial remarks ÃÂ including statements about the unconstitutionality of Medicare and Social Security
column3: as well as a proposal for seceding his state from the country he seeks to lead ÃÂ a Perry nomination would all but guarantee that the President will be stuck dealing with the 534 most difficult people in America for another four years.

column1: Realizing that even with a dismal sub-forty-percent approval rating
column2: he is still favored to win re-election
column3: President Obama has decided to consult Senator John Kerry and former Vice President Al Gore
column4: the two men who know more than anyone else about losing presidential elections to unqualified Texas governors.

column1: ÃÂItÃÂs all about doing everything you can to show the American people you know nothing about what theyÃÂre dealing with
column2: ÃÂ says former president-elect Al Gore. ÃÂIf the President talks about jobs while his opponents talk about tax cuts
column3: that will make him look sensible. He needs to start talking more about why his opponents are weirdos or crazy people if he is seriously considering losing this thing.ÃÂ

column1: ÃÂI think his problem is heÃÂs too consistent
column2: ÃÂ said Mr. Kerry. As an example
column3: Kerry cited the presidentÃÂs Afghanistan policy. ÃÂHe is doing exactly what he said he would do when he ran for president: focusing more troops fighting al Qaeda in the place they actually attacked us from. ItÃÂs ridiculous to do the same thing you said you would four years ago if you want to lose that job. Instead he should bow to his critics on the left and withdraw immediately.ÃÂ

column1: ÃÂNot really looking like you want the job and failing to communicate why your opponent is dangerously incompetent are also tried-and-true techniques
column2: ÃÂ added Gore. ÃÂHeÃÂs off to a good start there
column3: no question.ÃÂ

column1: To keep his options open if he decides he wants another term but ends up competing against the most threatening of the GOP contenders
column2: President Obama has begun consulting members of BushÃÂs 2004 re-election campaign as well. When a reporter asked one of the courted staffers why the Obama campaign was interested
column3: he replied he and his team ÃÂhave extensive experience working for an incumbent with terrible approval ratings while campaigning against a flip-flopper from Massachusetts.ÃÂ"	0

column1: 254	"The International Association of Firefighters
column2: the main union representing American firefighters
column3: has placed itself on a collision course with the AFL-CIO in the race for the next chairman of the Democratic National Committee
column4: deciding to back Labor Secretary Tom Perez over Minnesota Rep. Keith Ellison.

column1: The Democratic leadership contest has taken on unusual significance in the wake of Hillary Clinton's devastating loss last month
column2: dividing the labor movement between two Democrats whom it has long seen as allies.

column1: The AFL-CIO
column2: a federation of 55 unions that includes the IAFF
column3: endorsed Ellison just before Perez entered the race last week
column4: despite protests from IAFF President Harold Schaitberger and others.

column1: In a statement
column2: Schaitberger praised Perez as a ""a tireless advocate for civil and human rights"" who can transcend what the union president called ""a narrow focus on identity and cultural politics that alienated"" some longtime Democrats from the party.

column1: Tom Perez is the person who has the right mix of personal background
column2: progressive values
column3: experience and total commitment to all workers
column4: in all regions and states across the country
column5: Schaitberger said. ""To have Tom Perez as the Chair of one of our nation's two major political parties would be a significant victory for workers across America.""

column1: Perez
column2: the son of Dominican immigrants
column3: has been leaning on his heritage to appeal to Latino DNC members. But Schaitberger
column4: whose union is on the conservative end of the spectrum
column5: said the Labor Secretary is the best person to reorient the party around ""a strong economic message that is truly inclusive of everyone.""

column1: Ellison
column2: an African-American convert to Islam who supported Bernie Sanders in the Democratic presidential primary
column3: has faced questions over past associations with Nation of Islam founder Louis Farrakhan
column4: whom he long ago disowned.

column1: Schaitberger earlier spoke out against the AFL-CIO's endorsement process
column2: which gave its executive committee members only three options: Vote to endorse Ellison
column3: abstain
column4: or make no endorsement.

column1: That vote was an attempt to present a united front from the labor movement
column2: which is well represented among the voting members of the DNC
column3: and to avoid a damaging intraparty squabble.

column1: But the IAFF is the second major union in the AFL-CIO to back Perez
column2: and more defections may come.

column1: On Friday
column2: the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union ÃÂ one of the country's largest unions
column3: with 1.3 million members ÃÂ came out in support of the labor secretary
column4: saying its members ""saw firsthand his passion and commitment"" to their issues during his work heading the Department of Labor.

column1: Another union
column2: the United Farm Workers
column3: endorsed Perez on Monday. Their membership is small
column4: but the endorsement comes with a symbolic connection to famed labor leader Cesar Chavez
column5: who founded the union.

column1: He has been a lifelong friend of labor and immigrants. When farm workers needed him
column2: Tom Perez stood up and fought
column3: said UFW President Arturo Rodriguez
column4: noting it was the first time the union has ever endorsed in a DNC chair race. ""He played a key role in helping farm workers in California win the same overtime pay protections as all other workers
column5: and in doing so is helping end 78 years of race-based discrimination.""

However
column2: Ellison has the backing of a number of powerful individual unions in addition to the AFL-CIO

column4: County and Municipal Employees.

column1: Their support was a coup for Ellison not only because of their size
column2: but because both were active Clinton allies

column1: The election for DNC chair will be held in February during a party meeting in Atlanta

column1: 255	"Some time ago
column2: Hillary Clinton and her advisers decided that the best course of action was to apologize for having used a personal email address to conduct government business while serving as secretary of state. Clinton herself was
column3: clearly
column4: not really all that remorseful about this
column5: and it showed in her early efforts to address it. Eventually aides prevailed upon her to express a greater degree of regret
column6: which they hoped would lay the issue to rest.

column1: It did not. Instead
column2: email-related talk has dogged Clinton throughout the election and it has influenced public perceptions of her in an overwhelmingly negative way. July polling showed 56 percent of Americans believed Clinton broke the law by relying on a personal email address with another 36 percent piling on to say the episode showed ÃÂbad judgmentsÃÂ albeit not criminality.

column1: Because Clinton herself apologized for it and because it does not appear to be in any way important
column2: Clinton allies
column3: surrogates
column4: and co-partisans have largely not familiarized themselves with the details of the matter
column5: instead saying vaguely that it was an error of judgment and she apologized and America has bigger fish to fry.

column1: This has had the effect of further inscribing and reinscribing the notion that Clinton did something wrong
column2: meaning that every bit of micro-news that puts the scandal back on cable amounts to reminding people of something bad that Clinton did. In total
column3: network newscasts have
column4: remarkably
column5: dedicated more airtime to coverage of ClintonÃÂs emails than to all policy issues combined.

column1: This is unfortunate because emailgate
column2: like so many Clinton pseudo-scandals before it
column3: is bullshit. The real scandal here is the way a story that was at best of modest significance came to dominate the US presidential election ÃÂ overwhelming stories of much more importance
column4: giving the American people a completely skewed impression of one of the two nominees
column5: and creating space for the FBI to intervene in the election in favor of its apparently preferred candidate in a dangerous way.

column1: Why Hillary Clinton used a personal email account
When Hillary Clinton took office as secretary of state
column2: she
column3: like most people
column4: already had a personal email account. Like most people who started a federal job in 2009
column5: she was also disheartened to learn that the then-current state of federal IT departments was such that she could not connect her personal smartphone to a State Department email address. If she wanted ready access to both her email accounts
column6: she would need to carry two smartphones.

column1: As any reporter in Washington knows
column2: this indignity was in fact visited upon a huge number of DC denizens for many years. Everyone working in government felt that this was kinda bullshit
column3: but nobody could really do anything about it. (Meanwhile
column4: Chief Justice John Roberts has opined that carrying two phones could be reasonable grounds to suspect someone is a drug dealer.)

column1: Clinton decided to do something about it. Namely
column2: she told her top aides to just email her at her personal address so she could keep using whichever devices she wanted. This violated an internal State Department policy directive
column3: known as a Foreign Affairs Manual
column4: which stated that while it was okay to use personal digital devices to do work occasionally
column5: ÃÂnormal day-to-day operationsÃÂ should be conducted on standard State Department equipment. Clinton chose to ignore this guideline and because she was the boss nobody could stop her. Career foreign service officers and other State personnel have every right to be peeved that Clinton opted out of an annoying policy rather than fixing the underlying issue
column6: but itÃÂs hardly a matter of overwhelming public concern.

column1: And
column2: indeed
column3: it turns out Colin Powell also used a private email address for routine work. Condoleezza Rice and Madeleine Albright didnÃÂt use email
column4: and back before Albright only weird nerds even knew what email was. So at the time Clinton took office
column5: only one previous secretary of state had ever faced the question of what email account to use
column6: and he reached the exact same conclusion Clinton did ÃÂ just use your personal email address.

column1: Why Hillary used a private email server
When Hillary tried the eminently sensible ÃÂI was following precedentÃÂ defense
column2: Politifact dinged her answer as ÃÂmostly falseÃÂ on the grounds that while Powell did use a personal email account
column3: he didnÃÂt use a private email server.

column1: This distinction has attracted a lot of attention. And itÃÂs proven politically damaging ÃÂ because while lots of people maintain two email addresses and sometimes do work stuff on their personal email
column2: very few Americans use a private email server as opposed to relying on a commercial email service. But legally speaking
column3: this is completely irrelevant. As the State Department inspector general concluded in its report on ClintonÃÂs conduct
column4: the guideline Clinton violated was a principle that ÃÂnormal day-to-day operations should be conducted on an authorized Automated Information System.ÃÂ

column1: Using a private server violates that rule
column2: but so would using a Gmail address or simply checking your State.gov email address from your personal laptop rather than a Department-issue one.

column1: But while the use of a private server is legally irrelevant
column2: itÃÂs certainly unusual. And it leaves people wondering: Why did Clinton go out of her way to set up a private server?

column1: Clinton
column2: as you may have heard
column3: is married to former president Bill Clinton
column4: who stepped down from office in January of 2001. Clinton was in the White House throughout the 1990s when the rest of us were being bombarded with AOL signup CD-ROMs
column5: so he didnÃÂt have a personal email when he left. Gmail didnÃÂt exist back then
column6: and his new job was
column7: in effect
column8: running a Bill Clinton startup. He launched a charitable foundation
column9: he established his presidential library
column10: and he made big bucks on speaking tours. He had a staff and he needed IT infrastructure and support. So he paid a guy to set up an email server that he could use.

column1: Hillary Clinton ÃÂ who is
column2: again
column3: his wife ÃÂ also set herself up with an account on the same server. This is a bit unusual
column4: but a lot about being married to a former president is unusual. What itÃÂs not is suspicious.

column1: The private server was not a transparency dodge

ItÃÂs become a bit of an article of faith among journalists frustrated with public officialsÃÂ constant FOIA-dodging that this is all obviously dissimulation and Clinton was really trying to evade the Freedom of Information Act.
Many people
column2: for example
column3: point to the fact that Clinton would routinely travel with multiple digital devices as debunking her supposed convenience argument. But this is silly. IÃÂve been known to travel with an iPhone
column4: an iPad
column5: a Kindle
column6: and a laptop all at once. That doesnÃÂt mean needing to carry two separate iPhones (one to check my work email and one to check my personal email) wouldnÃÂt be inconvenient. After all
column7: what if I was replying to a work email while a text came in to my personal phone and I wanted to check it.

column1: IÃÂd be left juggling phones and looking like an idiot
column2: exactly how federal employees tended to look in the heyday of the double-fisting phones era.

column1: I would not want to do that. Colin Powell did not want to do that. Hillary Clinton did not want to do that. Because that would be terrible.
By contrast
column2: itÃÂs a terrible solution to a desire to avoid having your emails disclosed to the public via FOIA. One way you can tell itÃÂs a terrible solution is that Hillary ClintonÃÂs work emails have been disclosed to the public. You can read them right here.

column1: The specific timeline is that the House Select Committee on Benghazi requested ClintonÃÂs emails in the summer of 2014
column2: at which point the relevant State Department personnel realized they did not have the emails because Clinton had been using her personal address. State asked Clinton for the emails
column3: and she handed them over later that year. It was only in March of 2015 that the New York Times broke the story of ClintonÃÂs personal email account in a scoop by Michael Schmidt (the server was reported a few days later by the AP)*
column4: which reported that the emails had been handed over to the State Department ÃÂtwo months ago.ÃÂ

column1: This is fairly clearly not an optimal approach to government record-keeping
column2: as Thomas Blanton of the National Security Archive at George Washington University told Schmidt at the time:

column1: ItÃÂs a shame it didnÃÂt take place automatically when she was secretary of state as it should have. Someone in the State Department deserves credit for taking the initiative to ask for the records back. Most of the time it takes the threat of litigation and embarrassment.
According to the Inspector GeneralÃÂs report
column2: Clinton ÃÂshould have preserved any Federal records she created and received on her personal account by printing and filing those records with the related files in the Office of the Secretary.ÃÂ

column1: There are two possible interpretations here. One is that Clinton hatched the private email account plan as an elaborate dodge of federal record-keeping laws
column2: but then months before the public became aware of the serverÃÂs existence complied with requests to turn them over. The other is that the federal records rule on the book was antiquated and a bit absurd
column3: requiring officials to turn over paper copies of emails for no good reason
column4: and simply got ignored out of sloppiness.

column1: But she deleted 33
column2: 000 emails!

column1: Suspicion at this point is then supposed to focus on the fact that she had her lawyers delete more than 30
column2: 000 emails from her server.

column1: After Hillary left office
column2: the State Department told her she had to turn all her work-related emails over to them
column3: so she tasked a legal team with determining which emails were work emails and which were not. She turned the work emails over because thatÃÂs what she was legally required to do. She deleted the others
column4: presumably because she did not want Trey Gowdy and Jason Chaffetz to rummage through her inbox leaking whatever they happened to find amusing to area journalists.

column1: Now
column2: is it possible that ClintonÃÂs legal team simply decided to entirely disregard the law and delete work-related emails?

column1: In some sense
column2: sure. But thereÃÂs no evidence that this happened. Generally speaking
column3: in life we assume it would be moderately difficult to hire a well-known law firm to destroy evidence for you without someone deciding to do the right thing and squeal.

column1: Besides which
column2: it would be almost comically easy to catch Clinton in the act of systematically destroying relevant emails. The vast majority of the work-related email correspondence of an incumbent secretary of state
column3: after all
column4: is going to be correspondence with other government employees. Maybe she shoots a note to the Pentagon about Benghazi
column5: or circulates ideas for a speech draft with her communications team. Any message like that
column6: by definition
column7: would exist on a government server as well as on her private one. This means it would be fully accessible via FOIA and also means that if ClintonÃÂs copy were found to not be in the pile of emails she turned over
column8: sheÃÂd be caught red handed.

column1: The available FOIA workarounds are available to everyone
Now whatÃÂs true is that Clinton could
column2: in theory
column3: have conducted work-related email conversations using another personÃÂs personal email address.

column1: She could
column2: for instance
column3: have emailed Jake Sullivan on his Gmail address then deleted the email from her private server. WeÃÂd be in the dark and sheÃÂd get away with it.

column1: The key thing to note here
column2: however
column3: is that the availability of this option has nothing to do with ClintonÃÂs decision to use a personal account as her exclusive account and also has nothing to do with her decision to host her personal email on a private server.

column1: At any given time
column2: any federal employee can use her personal account to email any other federal employee at his personal account. If they receive a Freedom of Information Act request
column3: they are legally obligated to hand that correspondence over. But in a practical sense
column4: if they want to break the law they can probably get away with it. And as Ezra Klein has noted
column5: there are a lot of workarounds here:

column1: As every reporter knows
column2: when official sources want to tell you something particularly delicate
column3: they email you from a personal account ÃÂ or
column4: much more often
column5: they call.

column1: A lot of my reporting happens by email. But virtually none of my reporting with the White House happens by email. There
column2: emails for clarification
column3: or comment
column4: quickly lead to phone calls. The reason ÃÂ unsaid but obvious ÃÂ is that phone calls don't leave an official record. White House officials can talk freely on the phone in a way they can't over email.

column1: Similarly
column2: the White House keeps a visitor's log. If you make an appointment to meet with someone
column3: your entrance and point of contact are recorded for posterity and searchable online. When someone who shouldn't be meeting with you wants to meet with you
column4: they tend to suggest an off-site location: a restaurant downtown
column5: or a nearby coffee shop. Peet's Coffee doesn't keep a list of everyone who walks in or out.

column1: We do not
column2: however
column3: generally treat all federal employees as having a massive ethical cloud over their heads just because they could probably use this workaround to break the law. There is zero reason to apply heightened scrutiny to Clinton just because she also could break the law.

column1: Besides which
column2: when you are secretary of state there is a much simpler and easier way to mask your correspondence: classification.

column1: Here
column2: for example
column3: is an email Sullivan sent to Clinton on June 4
column5: that was duly handed over to the State Department and made available by the FOIA office:

column1: IÃÂm not saying the contents of that message donÃÂt deserve to be redacted for security purposes. The fact is that I have no idea. But the reality is the American national security state is really
column2: really good at using official channels to avoid disclosure of information. Nobody needs a private email server to pull that off.

column1: Indeed
column2: the allegation that the server setup was an elaborate con to evade transparency law is doubly ridiculous. On the one hand
column3: a private server would not be necessary to carry it out. (All you need is to have a private email address on the side
column4: which everyone does.) While on the other hand
column5: the exclusive use of a personal email account means that ClintonÃÂs personal account has come under an exceptional level of security.

column1: The classification thing is a red herring
ItÃÂs precisely because nothing about the basic setup of the email account was in any way wrong that the investigation ended up focusing on the question of mishandling classified information.
The key point here is that using a State.gov email account would not have changed anything. When US government officials have conversations about classified matters
column2: they are not supposed to use email. They are supposed to use special secure channels.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: mistakes happen in part because classification standards are vague and ever-changing. Technically speaking
column3: forwarding a Washington Post article detailing things revealed by Edward Snowden could constitute an improper discussion of classified matters.

column1: As FBI Director James Comey concluded
column2: ÃÂno reasonable prosecutorÃÂ would bring a case against Clinton over this matter. Almost all of the relevant statutes require an intent to mishandle classified information in order to bring a prosecution
column3: a standard that ClintonÃÂs conduct clearly does not meet. Critics have thus chosen to focus on 18 USC ÃÂ§ 793
column4: a statute that sets a lower ÃÂgross negligenceÃÂ standard.

column1: However
column2: as Jack Goldsmith
column3: one of the top lawyers in George W. BushÃÂs administration explains
column4: such a prosecution ÃÂwould be entirely novel
column5: and would turn in part on very tricky questions about how email exchanges fit into language written with physical removal of classified information in mind.ÃÂ

column1: Ben Wittes
column2: a veteran legal journalist and Brookings fellow who has spent the past several years specializing in national security law
column3: wrote that ComeyÃÂs characterization was clearly correct:

column1: For the last several months
column2: people have been asking me what I thought the chances of an indictment were. I have said each time that there is no chance without evidence of bad faith action of some kind. People simply don't get indicted for accidental
column3: non-malicious mishandling of classified material. I have followed leak cases for a very long time
column4: both at the Washington Post and since starting Lawfare. I have never seen a criminal matter proceed without even an allegation of something more than mere mishandling of sensitive information. Hillary Clinton is not above the law
column5: but to indict her on these facts
column6: she'd have to be significantly below the law.

column1: ItÃÂs true that to a layman the Espionage ActÃÂs reference to ÃÂgross negligenceÃÂ sounds similar to ComeyÃÂs characterization of ClintonÃÂs actions as ÃÂextremely careless.ÃÂ But as Philip Zelikow
column2: a counselor to Condoleezza Rice during the Bush administration and currently the Director of the Miller Center at the University of Virginia explains
column3: they only sound alike ÃÂunless you do a tiny bit of homeworkÃÂ on the history and caselaw of the Statute.

column1: Did Hillary Clinton do something criminal with her emails? Philip Zelikow walks you through. #election2016 @AnnCompton @pastpunditry pic.twitter.com/kS8Z4dq9Qf
ÃÂ Miller Center (@Miller_Center) November 3
As the Cato InstituteÃÂs Julian Sanchez writes
column2: attempting a prosecution for non-malicious mishandling would likely result in the statute being held unconstitutional: ÃÂthe Supreme CourtÃÂs opinion in Gorin v. United States (1941)
column3: which suggests that the Espionage ActÃÂs intent requirements are an important feature that save it from unconstitutional vagueness.ÃÂ

column1: This legal analysis is important because it makes it clear that even if the Weiner laptop emails arenÃÂt simply client-side copies of the exact emails the FBI already has
column2: there is essentially no chance it will change the ultimate verdict. The reason Clinton isnÃÂt getting locked up is that there was no malign intent. Finding another email with classified information on it wonÃÂt change that conclusion.

column1: A bullshit scandal amidst a serious election
Network newscasts have
column2: remarkably
column3: dedicated more airtime to coverage of ClintonÃÂs emails than to all policy issues combined.

column1: Cable news has been
column2: if anything
column3: worse
column4: and many prestige outlets have joined the pileup. One malign result of obsessive email coverage is that the public is left totally unaware of the policy stakes in the election. Another is that the constant vague recitations of the phrase ÃÂÃÂClinton email scandalÃÂÃÂ have firmly implanted the notion that there is something scandalous about anything involving Hillary Clinton and email
column5: including her campaign manager getting hacked or the revelation that one of her aides sometimes checked mail on her husbandÃÂs computer.

column1: But none of this is true. Clinton broke no laws according to the FBI itself. Her setup gave her no power to evade federal transparency laws beyond what anyone who has a personal email account of any kind has. Her stated explanation for her conduct is entirely believable
column2: fits the facts perfectly
column3: and is entirely plausible to anyone who doesn't simply start with the assumption that she's guilty of something.

column1: Given PowellÃÂs conduct
column2: Clinton wasn't even breaking with an informal precedent. The very worst you can say is that
column3: faced with an annoying government IT policy
column4: she used her stature to find a personal workaround rather than a systemic fix that would work for everyone. To spend so much time on such a trivial matter would be absurd in a city council race
column5: much less a presidential election. To do so in circumstances when it advances the electoral prospects of a rival who has shattered all precedents in terms of lacking transparency or basic honesty is infinitely more scandalous than anything related to the server itself."	0

column1: 261	"WASHINGTON ÃÂ The very first President's Intelligence Checklist ÃÂ the predecessor to what's now known as the President's Daily Briefing ÃÂ was delivered to President John F. Kennedy on a June Saturday in 1961. Typewritten on eight pages of 8.5-by-8-inch paper and stamped ""For the President Only ÃÂ Top Secret
column2: it contained 14 two-sentence briefs culled from diplomatic
column3: military
column4: intelligence and press sources
column5: six shorter notes
column6: and maps of Laos and the Congo.

column1: Today
column2: President Obama receives the document on an iPad. The articles are somewhat longer and sometimes have dissenting opinions. The maps can be interactive
column3: and the briefings can include video.

column1: The differences aren't just technological. After serving 10 presidents ÃÂ and now preparing to brief the 11th
column2: President-elect Donald Trump ÃÂ the President's Daily Briefing has had to adjust to the reading habits and decision-making styles of each commander in chief.

column1: And the ways in which it's produced
column2: read and discussed provide a rare insight into how presidents approach national security issues.

column1: ItÃÂs the only standing meeting he has every day. Even if we donÃÂt have the meeting
column2: he gets the document
column3: said Obama's deputy national security adviser
column4: Ben Rhodes. ""Everyday there's the possibility that he'll see something that will cause him to move the entire U.S. government in a new direction. There's nothing else like that.""

column1: For Obama
column2: the PDB process paints a portrait of a methodical president who's often disdainful of raw
column3: unfiltered intelligence in favor of more analytical perspective. He encourages dissenting opinions. He's interested in ""open source"" intelligence ÃÂ including press accounts and
column4: increasingly
column5: social media ÃÂ in addition to old-fashioned spycraft and intercepted communications.

column1: President-elect Trump has yet to make a formal mark on intelligence. He's still getting a daily intelligence briefing designed for
column2: and catered to
column3: Obama. He's reading it largely as a courtesy by the incumbent president
column4: part of a bipartisan tradition dating back to President Harry Truman.

column1: But Trump has already suggested a different style of receiving intelligence. For the first month
column2: he received in-person intelligence briefings only once a week
column3: although his transition team now says it's three times a week.

column1: But Trump himself has suggested a more ad hoc system of being updated only when major developments warrant.
I get it when I need it
column2: Trump told Fox News Sunday.

column1: I don't have to be told the same thing in the same words every single day for the next eight years
column2: he said. ""I don't need that. But I do say
column3: 'If something should change
column4: let us know.' ""

column1: In skipping daily briefings
column2: Trump shows ambivalence toward intel agencies

column1: Aides: Trump gets frequent classified briefings
Obama has said much the same about his daily briefing ÃÂ albeit much later in his presidency.
Over the years
column2: you accumulate knowledge
column3: Obama said in a YouTube interview earlier this year. ""Now
column4: I've got enough of a baseline of knowledge. I've seen problems come up before
column5: I've seen patterns that have emerged. I might not have to go into the briefing book as deeply as I did. ... I'm skimming. I'm looking at
column6: are there significant differences?""

column1: The frequency
column2: the duration
column3: the format
column4: the depth
column5: the subject matter ÃÂ even the distribution list ÃÂ are all up to the president.

column1: In a book published earlier this year
column2: former CIA officer David Priess argued that the PDB has had to adapt to each president who has receives it ÃÂ and will continue to evolve to meet the president's personality
column3: learning style and priorities.

column1: If a new president comes in and he wants the PDB presented through interpretive dance
column2: he or she will get that
column3: said Priess
column4: author of The President's Book of Secrets: The Untold Story of Intelligence Briefings. ""There will be a whole lot of intelligence officers taking dancing lessons.""

column1: The President's Daily Briefing is what its name implies
column2: Priess said.

column1: It is brief. Everything is not going to make it in. ItÃÂs daily. If itÃÂs not breaking
column2: or not current
column3: it doesnÃÂt get in
column4: he said. ""But the most important word is 'president.' Is this deserving of his attention?""

column1: That's a question that the intelligence community is constantly trying to reassess. And the transition period is a critical time for the incoming president to get up to speed on intelligence issues ÃÂ and for the intelligence community to get to know the president-elect.
Current and former national security officials say frequent
column2: in-person briefings with the president ÃÂ and the president-elect ÃÂ are an essential part of making sure the commander in chief is well-informed.

column1: There is a certain amount of trial and error to really settle in to what the new team wants
column2: former CIA director Michael Hayden said. In his book
column3: Playing to the Edge: American Intelligence in the Age of Terror
column4: he describes what the intelligence community crudely refers to as the ""aw
column5: s---"" moment.

column1: Michael Hayden is a retired Air Force four-star general
Michael Hayden is a retired Air Force four-star general
column2: former director of the National Security Agency and former director of the CIA. (Photo: Jasper Colt
column3: USA TODAY)

column1: It's attempt by intelligence officials to challenge the worldview of the president-elect's political advisers with a dose of reality. Hayden calls it ""phenomenon of the unpleasant fact.""

That's when the intelligence guys give the president information and analysis that cuts across the policy or politics grain of the administration. You're telling them something they donÃÂt want to hear and donÃÂt want to believe
column2: he said.

column1: And it's important to do that in an in-person briefing
column2: as opposed to the written product. ""You have to shake the preferred narrative of the policymaker
column3: Hayden said. ""And you need the ability to do that face to face
column4: and to do it with your tone
column5: and your words and your body language to communicate
column6: as opposed to just throwing it over the transom.""

column1: When Obama first took office
column2: the intelligence community grumbled that Obama ÃÂ or at least his national security staff ÃÂ wanted the reports so brief that they called them ""PDB haiku.""

column1: Hayden's early briefings of Obama (he was replaced three weeks into Obama's presidency) were ""far less tactical"" than the briefings President George W. Bush was receiving.
But Michael Leiter
column2: who directed the National Counterterrorism Center under both Bush and Obama
column3: said he saw Obama grow in his use of intelligence from those early months.

column1: His inclination from the start was less about the tactics and more about the strategy
column2: and more about how the U.S. was perceived in the world and interacted in the world
column3: he said.

column1: But there certainly was an evolution. To me
column2: that was most crystallized
column3: around the time of underwear bomber
column4: he said
column5: referring to the Christmas Day 2009 plot to bring down a Detroit-bound airliner. ""That so changed the president's perception of how detail oriented he had to be on these things.""

column1: From then on
column2: he said
column3: any terrorism threat the president was briefed about also had to include an operational briefing about what was being done to address it.

column1: Still
column2: it's a difficult balancing act for the president and his briefing team. Rhodes said the president needs to be disciplined enough not to be distracted by the uncorroborated bits of information ÃÂ or to attribute more credibility to information only because it's classified. ""Sometimes you are so focused on what is secret that you're not looking at what's right in front of your eyes
column3: Rhodes said in an interview with USA TODAY before the election.

column1: ItÃÂs worrisome to get into raw intelligence
column2: he said. ""Because you may have some intercept that you think is great
column3: but it could be some official in some country
column4: it could be just their view
column5: or what they hope happens. Or
column6: sometimes they know that the (National Security Agency) is listening
column7: and they want us to intercept that raw intelligence. That's where the job of ODNI is very hard.""

column1: Deputy National Security Adviser for Strategic Communication
Deputy National Security Adviser for Strategic Communication Ben Rhodes (Photo: Mandel Ngan
column2: AFP/Getty Images)

column1: ODNI is the Office of the Director of National Intelligence
column2: an office created by Congress in 2004 in a series of post-9/11 intelligence reforms. While the briefing is assembled by ODNI with input from the entire intelligence community
column3: the CIA ÃÂ by virtue of its historic role and experience in analysis ÃÂ still has an outsized role in the process.

column1: Obama has said he's conscientious about hearing from a broad array of experts. ""I've learned to be pretty good at listening carefully to people who know a lot more than I do about a topic
column2: Obama said in the YouTube interview. ""And taking sure that any dissenting voices are in the same room at the same time.""

column1: But while Obama says he listens to all voices
column2: not all of those voices feel that they're being heard.

column1: A 2014 report from the Intelligence Community Inspector General interviewed intelligence analysts across the government and found that ""broader community participation in the President's Daily Brief (PDB) remains a challenge.""

Rhodes said the president has increasingly asked for lower-level analysts who are experts in a political topic to brief him personally ÃÂ a practice that has been going on at least since Jimmy Carter's presidency. ""Let's get the analysts who are living through these issues every day
column2: Rhodes said. ""He likes that
column3: so he's tried to do that more.""

column1: The daily book often contains dissenting views
column2: which Leiter said were ""often the most illuminating thing in a PDB article.""

column1: And under Obama
column2: non-urgent raw intelligence often gets shopped around the intelligence community for corroboration and analysis before making it to the president. And highly sensitive information gleaned from top-secret sources and methods is balanced with open-source intelligence ÃÂ the kind of information that's available to anyone reading a newspaper.

column1: 'Rebalancing' the PDB
Presidents
column2: of course
column3: also send signals back to the intelligence community about their policy priorities ÃÂ and that gets reflected in their briefings.

column1: Richard Nixon's had a heavy emphasis on Vietnam and China. Ronald Reagan's was almost singularly obsessed with the Soviet Union. And for the last two presidents
column2: the Middle East has dominated the PDB ÃÂ to the extent that the White House has occasionally had to remind intelligence agencies that Obama wants a wider aperture.

column1: You could write the PDB every day and never talk about anything except the Middle East and Russia
column2: Rhodes said. ""To the point where weÃÂve had to say
column3: 'Hey
column4: guys
column5: we're rebalancing to the Asia-Pacific. Make sure that's represented in the PDB.' You almost have to reach out for that stuff
column6: because it doesn't always naturally come up.""

column1: Obama's PDB also increasingly includes information on economic
column2: environmental and public health crises that could have an impact on national security. And they're not necessarily confined to foreign affairs. Last summer
column3: deputy press secretary Eric Schultz confirmed that Obama had been briefed on the spread of the Zika virus in Florida as part of his daily intelligence briefing.

column4: Va. (Photo: Saul Loeb

column1: World's most exclusive newspaper
The President's Daily Briefing
column2: also known as ""the book
column3: is among the most secret documents the government keeps. For a time
column4: even its very existence was thought to be classified.

column1: It's just one of dozens of products regularly produced by the intelligence community. But because it gets the attention of the commander in chief
column2: it has a sense of urgency and importance ÃÂ and even mystique ÃÂ that other top secret documents don't have.

column1: Today it is such a vital part of how the White House operates that one can hardly imagine the modern presidency without it
column2: said CIA Director John Brennan as the agency declassified 2
column3: 500 briefings to Presidents Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson last year. ""The PDB is the most abundantly staffed
column4: most deeply sourced daily information service in the world.""

column1: It's been referred to as the world's most exclusive daily newspaper
column2: written exclusively for the president of the United States.

column1: But presidents can and do share the PDB with a small circle of advisers.
Kennedy never shared his with his vice president. Nixon deeply distrusted the CIA and often ignored the briefing
column2: instead delegating it to national security adviser Henry Kissinger.

column1: The younger Bush restricted the distribution to just six or seven people. In the Obama administration
column2: the distribution list is thought to be as many as two dozen
column3: including the secretary of State. In her book Hard Choices
column4: Clinton called the hand-delivered report the ""first order of business"" after getting to the office each morning. Her schedules
column5: released under the Freedom of Information Act
column6: often allotted the first five minutes of every morning to reading the PDB.

column1: The president could even share the briefing with members of his family. Trump and his family have denied reports that he's sought security clearances for his children and for son-in-law Jared Kushner
column2: but the president is the ultimate authority on how classified information can be shared and with whom.

column1: Trump has also raised eyebrows by appearing to question the CIA's integrity in the wake of reports that the spy agency had concluded that Russia deliberately interfered in the election to get Trump elected. ""These are the same people that said Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction
column2: the Trump transition said in a statement to reporters last week.

column1: That prompted the White House to defend the intelligence officers ÃÂ and suggest that Trump would do well to listen to them.
President ObamaÃÂs experience over the last eight years has been that the men and women of the intelligence community in the United States are patriots
column2: White House press secretary Josh Earnest said Monday. ""President Obama is certainly not the first president to have enjoyed the benefits of the experts in our intelligence community
column3: and I'm confident the president-elect would benefit from that advice if he remains open to it.""

column1: 272	"During a 33-year career at the Central Intelligence Agency

column3: not once

column5: unrepentantly and unapologetically? We stand against bullying in schools. ShouldnÃÂt we do the same in presidential politics?

column1: Could concerns be raised about other Christian candidates? Absolutely. But the concern of this article is not policy but tone and decorum. Prior presidents have exercised a restraint of the tongue. ItÃÂs hard to imagine George H.W. Bush using locker room language to demean an opponent on a debate stage. I didnÃÂt vote for President Obama

column4: teachers
column5: coaches and
column6: by all means

column1: All of them.
The stock explanation for Mr. TrumpÃÂs success is this: He has tapped into the anger of the American people. As one man said

column1: But what do their plans mean for your federal tax liability?
We partnered with the Tax Policy Center to create a calculator that will estimate how each presidential candidate's tax plan would affect you ÃÂ or
column2: more accurately
column3: people like you. For example
column4: if you are part of a couple with two children earning $38
column5: 000 a year

column8: 000 a year.

column1: Before you change your vacation plans based on these numbers

column3: for example
column4: while another person will be paying a tax for not carrying insurance coverage. This creates millions of different scenarios.

column1: Accounting for all of that is prohibitively complicated and time-consuming. But what we have done is simplify the process to consider only the biggest factors (income

column3: and children) and only look at the four taxes with the largest impact (individual and corporate income taxes

column1: Try it yourself below.

(Note: The Tax Policy Center did not perform an analysis of John Kasich's tax plan because his plan lacks sufficient detail to model. They have reached out to the Kasich campaign in search of more details
column2: and will analyze the plan if they receive enough information to do so.)

column1: The calculator: How much does each candidate's tax plan affect you?

column2: he writes:

column1: In a sense
column2: both GOP candidates are gaming the calculator: They've proposed tremendous cuts
column3: but without knowing who will pay for those cuts

column1: On Sanders

column1: Sanders
column2: meanwhile

column5: to view Sanders's plan as primarily a change to America's tax code. The huge tax increases are a byproduct of Sanders's plans to nationalize major sectors of American life.

column1: Read the full analysis here.

Update on why rates are higher than you think: We've been getting a lot of questions about why your current effective tax rate is so high. Here's a note from Tax Policy Center director Len Burman that explains why this is happening:
You might be surprised at how much taxes youÃÂre paying under current law. WeÃÂre including payroll taxes
column2: excise taxes
column3: and corporate income taxes as well as individual income taxes. Most working people actually pay more in payroll tax than income tax. And they pay much more if you include the employerÃÂs portion of the tax. Most economists think employers pass their share of the tax on to workers in the form of lower wages.

column1: Update
column2: plus a FAQ section: To calculate the tax rate
column3: we originally used adjusted gross income (AGI)
column4: but we decided to switch over to expanded cash income (ECI)
column5: because this measure includes income that is not subject to income tax
column6: like health insurance premiums paid by employers. This allows the calculator to provide a more accurate view of your tax rate. For a longer explanation
column7: read this Q&A.

column1: What we learned from our calculator
Play around with different incomes other than your own to get a better idea of how each candidate deals with the poor
column2: middle class
column3: and wealthy.

column1: In short
column2: what you'll see is:

column1: Clinton proposes keeping things mostly the same.
Sanders wants to implement massive increases across the board
column2: including on the poor.

column1: Cruz and Trump propose big cuts for everyone ÃÂ but the wealthier you are
column2: the more you keep in your pocket.

column1: But how does this affect how much money the federal government brings in?
It's one thing to know how your taxes will change
column2: but you can't view it in a vacuum. What the federal government does can affect your bottom line
column3: too.

column1: For example
column2: Bernie Sanders's plan would raise taxes on everyone
column3: but it would also pay for health care
column4: education
column5: and other programs that you would no longer have to pay for. And it goes the other way
column6: too. If Donald Trump's tax plan was implemented
column7: everyone would get a tax cut
column8: but it also means government services would be cut
column9: so you would have to pay for them yourself.

column1: So this is how each candidate deals with this balance:
Donald Trump: His plan would cut federal revenues by an estimated $9.5 trillion over the next decade. Cuts would be across the board
column2: but most cuts would be for wealthier households. His tax cuts promise to stimulate economic growth and reduce government spending
column3: which could cause households to pay more for services that are currently subsidized by the government. (Here are more details on Trump's plan.)

column1: Ted Cruz: His plan would cut federal revenues by an estimated $8.6 trillion over the next decade. Much like Trump's plan
column2: cuts would be across the board
column3: but most cuts are for wealthier households. His tax cuts promise to stimulate economic growth and reduce government spending
column4: which could cause households to pay more for services that are currently subsidized by the government. (Here are more details on Cruz's plan.)

column1: Hillary Clinton: Her plan would raise federal revenues by an additional $1.1 trillion over the next decade. Most increases would be for wealthier households
column2: while lower-income households aren't affected much. The additional revenues will pay for programs that benefit many Americans. (Here are more details on Clinton's plan.)

column1: Bernie Sanders: His plan would raise federal revenues by an estimated $15.3 trillion over the next decade. He would raise taxes for almost all households
column2: but most increases would be for wealthier households; tax increases would be small for lower- and middle-income households. Additional revenues would pay for health care
column3: education
column4: and other programs
column5: so households would pay less than what they currently pay for those services. (Here are more details on Sanders's plan.)"	0

It happened because of prison overcrowding. Prison overcrowding creates unconstitutional conditions for inmates. Anything that can be done to relieve those unconstitutional conditions is welcome.
For those who have not paid much attention to prison overcrowding
column2: the U.S. Supreme Court case of Brown v. Plata is an eye opener. Although it affects only the California prison system
column3: it focuses attention on overcrowded conditions in state and federal prisons alike. Writing for the majority in that case
column4: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy said that California prisons were designed to house a population of 80
column5: 000 but that the population was close to double that. ÃÂPrisonersÃÂ he said
column6: ÃÂare crammed into spaces neither designed nor intended to house inmates... [S]uicidal inmates may be held for prolonged periods in telephone booth sized cages without toilets ÃÂ and the lack of care results in ÃÂneedless suffering and death.ÃÂ Stating the often overlooked but obvious truism
column7: Justice Kennedy says that even though incarcerated
column8: ÃÂPrisoners retain the essence of human dignity inherent in all persons. Respect for that dignity animates the Eighth Amendment prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.ÃÂ He concludes his opinion saying that ÃÂThe medical and mental health care provided by CaliforniaÃÂs prisons falls below the standard of decency that inheres in the Eighth Amendment.ÃÂ

column1: Overcrowding is a problem in federal prisons as well. According to The Crime Report
column2: when the U.S. Attorney for Atlanta
column3: Sally Quillian Yates
column4: was testifying before the U.S. Sentencing Commission in Washington in late May 2010
column5: she said that federal facilities are currently operating at 34 percent above capacity. In her testimony she said that the overcrowding will have ÃÂreal and detrimental consequences for the safety of prisoners.ÃÂ Her concerns are echoed by Bryan Lowry
column6: president of the American Federation of Government EmployeesÃÂ Council of Prison Locals. Testifying before a House Appropriations subcommittee in 2010 he pointed out to the committee that between June 2008 and the time of his testimony in March 2010
column7: there were 340 inmate-on-staff assaults in federal prisons nationwide. He told the committee that ÃÂThese aggressive acts by inmates against staff illustrate a common reality facing staff daily at their workplace. Federal prisons have continued to be increasingly dangerous places to work
column8: primarily because of serious correctional worker understaffing and prison inmate overcrowding problems.ÃÂ And that all serves to highlight what we learned from the Platt case. Overcrowding violates the prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment that is proscribed by the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution. It also helps explain the death of Anwar al-Awlaki
column9: the United States citizen who was summarily executed by the United States Government because he had been designated a terrorist.

column1: Mr. Awlaki was killed September 30 in Yemen by a missile fired from a United States operated drone aircraft. Mr. Awlaki spent the first seven years of his life in Las Cruces New Mexico. His family moved to Yemen where he lived until he was 19 when he returned to the United States to attend college. Following his graduation he became an Imam at assorted mosques in the United States. Eventually he became a fiery preacher advocating the mass murder of American citizens.

In early 2010 the U.S. government said his actions made him a justifiable target for capture or death. His father objected to the fact that his son had been made death penalty eligible without having been tried or convicted of any offense. Aided by the ACLU he went to court alleging that the actions of the government in authorizing his sonÃÂs summary execution violated the due process clause of the U.S. Constitution. The judge threw out the lawsuit although he said that the actions of the government raised ÃÂstark
column2: and perplexing
column3: questionsÃÂ one of which was whether the president could ÃÂorder the assassination of a U.S. citizen without first affording him any form of judicial process whatsoever
column4: based [on] the mere assertion that he is a dangerous member of a terrorist organization.ÃÂ The question has now been answered. It can
column5: it did and Mr. Awlaki is now dead.

column1: In making its decision to kill Mr. Awlaki
column2: it is clear that the Obama administration was addressing two competing interests. If Mr. Awlaki was captured and sent to prison his 5th Amendment due process rights would be preserved but the other prisonersÃÂ 8th Amendment rights would be impinged by increasing the overcrowding. By killing him the administration was violating the constitutional rights of only one person instead of many. Examined in that light it is obvious that the government made the right decision. It should also cause the rest of the country to wonder how far the administration is willing to go to avoid further prison overcrowding. Time will tell."	0

309	"It seems weÃÂre entering another of those stupid seasons humans impose on themselves at fairly regular intervals.
My background is archaeology
column2: so also history and anthropology. It leads me to look at big historical patterns. My theory is that most peoplesÃÂ perspective of history is limited to the experience communicated by their parents and grandparents
column3: so 50-100 years. To go beyond that you have to read
column4: study and learn to untangle the propaganda that is inevitable in all telling of history. In a nutshell
column5: at university I would fail a paper if I didnÃÂt compare at least two
column6: if not three opposing views on a topic. Taking one telling of events as gospel doesnÃÂt wash in the comparative analytical method of research that forms the core of British academia. (I canÃÂt speak for other systems
column7: but theyÃÂre definitely not all alike in this way.)

column1: So zooming out
column2: we humans have a habit of going into phases of mass destruction
column3: generally self-imposed to some extent or another. This handy list shows all the wars over time. Wars are actually the norm for humans
column4: but every now and then something big comes along. I am interested in the Black Death
column5: which devastated Europe. The opening of BoccaccioÃÂs Decameron describes Florence in the grips of the Plague. It is as beyond imagination as the Somme
column6: Hiroshima or the Holocaust. I mean
column7: you quite literally canÃÂt put yourself there and imagine what it was like. For those in the midst of the Plague
column8: it must have felt like the end of the world.

column1: [Trump is] a charismatic narcissist who feeds on the crowd to become ever stronger
column2: creating a cult around himself.

column1: But a defining feature of humans is their resilience. To us now
column2: it seems obvious that we survived the Plague
column3: but to people at the time it must have seemed incredible that their society continued afterwards. Indeed
column4: many takes on the effects of the Black Death are that it had a positive impact in the long term. Well summed up here:

column1: By targeting frail people of all ages
column2: and killing them by the hundreds of thousands within an extremely short period of time
column3: the Black Death might have represented a strong force of natural selection and removed the weakest individuals on a very broad scale within Europe
column4: ÃÂ ...In addition
column5: the Black Death significantly changed the social structure of some European regions. Tragic depopulation created the shortage of working people. This shortage caused wages to rise. Products prices fell too. Consequently
column6: standards of living increased. For instance
column7: people started to consume more food of higher quality.

column1: But for the people living through it
column2: as with the World Wars
column3: Soviet Famines
column4: Holocaust
column5: it must have felt inconceivable that humans could rise up from it. The collapse of the Roman Empire
column6: Black Death
column7: Spanish Inquisition
column8: Thirty Years War
column9: War of the Roses
column10: English Civil War... itÃÂs a long list. Events of massive destruction from which humanity recovered and move on
column11: often in better shape.

column1: At a local level in time
column2: people think things are fine ÃÂ then things rapidly spiral out of control until they become unstoppable
column3: and we wreak massive destruction on ourselves. For the people living in the midst of this
column4: it is hard to see happening and hard to understand. To historians later
column5: it all makes sense and we see clearly how one thing led to another. During the Centenary of the Battle of the Somme I was struck that it was a direct outcome of the assassination of an Austrian Arch Duke in Bosnia. I very much doubt anyone at the time thought the killing of a minor European royal would lead to the death of 17 million people.

column1: My point is that this is a cycle. It happens again and again
column2: but as most people only have a 50-100 year historical perspective they donÃÂt see that itÃÂs happening again. As the events that led to the First World War unfolded

column6: mad
column7: or fools

Then after the War to end all Wars

column1: On a wider stage
column2: zoom out some more

column1: We should be asking ourselves what our Archduke Ferdinand moment will be. How will an apparently small event trigger another period of massive destruction. We see Brexit
column2: Trump
column3: Putin in isolation. The world does not work that way? ÃÂ? all things are connected and affecting each other. I have pro-Brexit friends who say
column4: ÃÂOh
column5: youÃÂre going to blame that on Brexit too??ÃÂ But they donÃÂt realize that actually
column6: yes
column7: historians will trace neat lines from apparently unrelated events back to major political and social shifts like Brexit.

column1: We are entering a bad phase. It will be unpleasant for those living through it
column2: maybe even will unravel into being hellish and beyond imagination.

column1: Brexit ÃÂ a group of angry people winning a fight ÃÂ easily inspires other groups of angry people to start a similar fight
column2: empowered with the idea that they may win. That alone can trigger chain reactions. A nuclear explosion is not caused by one atom splitting
column3: but by the impact of the first atom that splits causing multiple other atoms near it to split
column4: and they in turn causing multiple atoms to split. The exponential increase in atoms splitting
column5: and their combined energy is the bomb. That is how World War One started and
column6: ironically how World War Two ended.

column1: An example of how Brexit could lead to a nuclear war could be this:
Brexit in the UK causes Italy or France to have a similar referendum. Le Pen wins an election in France. Europe now has a fractured EU. The EU

column5: Slovakia

column1: This is just one Arch Duke Ferdinand scenario. The number of possible scenarios are infinite due to the massive complexity of the many moving parts. And of course many of them lead to nothing happening. But based on history we are due another period of destruction
column2: and based on history all the indicators are that we are entering one.

column1: It will come in ways we canÃÂt see coming
column2: and will spin out of control so fast people wonÃÂt be able to stop it. Historians will look back and make sense of it all and wonder how we could all have been so naÃÂ¯ve. How could I sit in a nice cafÃÂ© in London
column3: writing this
column4: without wanting to run away. How could people read it and make sarcastic and dismissive comments about how pro-Remain people should stop whining
column5: and how we shouldnÃÂt blame everything on Brexit. Others will read this and sneer at me for saying America is in great shape
column6: that Trump is a possible future Hitler (and yes

column8: charismatic leader fanning flames of hatred until things spiral out of control). ItÃÂs easy to jump to conclusions that oppose pessimistic predictions based on the weight of history and learning. Trump won against the other Republicans in debates by countering their claims by calling them names and dismissing them. ItÃÂs an easy route but the wrong one.

column3: is no different to ignoring a doctor who tells you to stop smoking

column1: We need to find a way to bridge from our closed groups to other closed groups

column1: What can we do? Well
column2: again

column1: 311	"With Democrats unable to stop President-elect Donald Trump's Cabinet picks on their own
column2: they're hoping that increased scrutiny on his nominees will do it for them.

column1: As the minority party in the Senate with little real recourse at their disposal
column2: uncovering something disqualifying may be Democrats' last best hope to block some Trump selections that they view as unacceptable and outside the political mainstream.

column1: Even if they don't have the votes to shoot down any nominees
column2: Democratic senators will grill them in committee hearings. They can slow the confirmation process with procedural moves or try to shame them ÃÂ all in the service of trying to peel off the three Republican votes they would need to kill a nomination or force the Trump White House to withdraw the pick.

column1: Not all of Trump's picks will face such aggressive scrutiny
column2: which Democrats insist is not merely reflexive partisan opposition. Retired Gen. James Mattis is expected to sail through his confirmation to be defense secretary
column3: even though his recent tenure in the active-duty military means he'll need a special waiver that requires 60 votes in the Senate.

column1: But some of Trump's picks
column2: Democrats say
column3: represent existential threats to the basic mission of the departments they've been tapped to lead
column4: and so the nominees have no business in those jobs.

column1: There's Trump's reported pick for secretary of state
column2: Rex Tillerson
column3: chief executive of oil giant ExxonMobil
column4: who has warm relations with Russian President Vladimir Putin. There's Trump's pick to head the Environmental Protection Agency
column5: Scott Pruitt
column6: who has made a name for himself by suing the agency. There's Andy Puzder
column7: Trump's choice for the Labor Department
column8: a fast food executive who wants to replace workers with robots.

column1: There's Betsy DeVos
column2: a school choice advocate seen as hostile to public education
column3: whom Trump wants to put in charge of the Education Department. And there's attorney general nominee Jeff Sessions
column4: an anti-immigration hard-liner whom the Senate once rejected for a federal judgeship over past racially insensitive comments.

column1: Democratic congressional aides and outside groups will spend the coming weeks poring over the financial statements
column2: personal histories and public utterances of Trump's most polarizing Cabinet selections
column3: hoping to find information that could turn them into the next Tom Daschle or Zoe Baird ÃÂ Barack Obama and Bill Clinton Cabinet nominees who were forced to withdraw after damaging issues came to light during the confirmation process.

column1: And Democrats have reason to believe Trump's nominees provide an especially rich vein for digging
column2: because according to reports
column3: few have been subjected to a traditionally thorough vetting process by his transition team. Many are wealthy business executives with sprawling financial entanglements and no political experience or the scrutiny that comes with it.

column1: What's unusual about Trump's Cabinet picks is that so few of them come from politics
column2: which means that they're going to have a harder time than usual going through the traditional vet and public evaluation
column3: said Simon Rosenberg
column4: president of the Democratic think tank NDN. ""Some of them are going to crash. Some of them aren't going to make it because of things that are going to come up in their background.""

column1: Democrats will have to pick their battles
column2: and priorities will likely be decided based not only by how threatening they find Trump's nominees
column3: but how vulnerable the nominees are after some digging.

column1: Related: Donald Trump Builds Cabinet with Old Friends and Some Rivals
Much of it depends on what's uncovered in the vetting process
column2: said Jim Manley
column3: a former aide to Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid of Nevada. ""As Senator Daschle found out
column4: one little thing can trip you up.""

column1: Daschle was nominated to head the Department of Health and Human Services in 2009 but removed his name after controversy over his taxes emerged.
Old domestic abuse allegations related to a messy divorce have already surfaced with Puzder. But complicated financial issues are more likely to trip up Trump's nominees than personal indiscretions
column2: especially given the number of super-wealthy candidates Trump has chosen.

column1: The Senate Finance Committee has developed a reputation as somewhat of a killing field for nominees in recent years
column2: Manley said. ""They've developed the experience to really pick apart the financials.""

column1: And Trump's team may be flying blind to some extent. His transition team has reportedly forgone the rigorous vetting process traditionally performed on potential nominees before they are announced publicly
column2: leaving his picks potentially vulnerable to surprises.

column1: Selecting Rep. Mike Pompeo
column2: R-kansas
column3: as CIA director was ""pretty simple
column4: said Rep. Devin Nunes
column5: R-California
column6: who is working on Trump's transition team.

column1: They asked me who would be the person for the agency
column2: and I said without a doubt that Pompeo would be a great pick
column3: Nunes told Politico.

column1: Dan Kanninen
column2: a former Obama White House official who helped choose candidates for jobs in the Environmental Protection Agency
column3: said it takes weeks or months for even the best transition teams to properly vet candidates.

column1: With Trump
column2: none of that
column3: as far as we can tell
column4: happened before the election. And now
column5: if it is happening at all
column6: it's happening in a matter of days based on the gut on the president-elect
column7: he said. ""It would not surprise me at all
column8: given how little we know ÃÂ and frankly how little the Trump team knows ÃÂ if something came up with of a magnitude that might kill some of their nominations.""

column1: Even under the best of circumstances
column2: things get missed. Clinton rescinded Baird's nomination to be attorney general because it was discovered that she had hired an undocumented immigrant as a nanny.

column1: The Senate confirmation process can be brutal even for squeaky clean candidates who have spent their whole careers in government. A ""Survivor's Guide for Presidential Nominees"" prepared by the National Academy of Public Administration
column2: a congressionally chartered non-profit
column3: stretches over 71 pages and warns
column4: ""If you are not nervous going into your confirmation hearing
column5: you should be.""

column1: It may be especially bumpy for Trump's nominees from the private sector
column2: who are not accustomed to government processes and who have not already gone through the kind of public and legal scrutiny politicians and government officials are used to.

column1: Three years ago
column2: facing Republican obstruction
column3: Senate Democrats decided to kill the filibuster for executive branch appointments
column4: which means they now cannot force Republicans to find the 60 votes needed to break a filibuster. Republicans need only 51 votes in the Senate to confirm Trump's Cabinet picks.

column1: Democrats would need three Republicans to join them to shoot down any of Trump's nominees
column2: and so far none have expressed interest in taking up the cause.

column1: Some Democrats
column2: unsurprisingly
column3: are having buyer's remorse about the filibuster change
column4: including Reid's successor as Democratic Leader
column5: Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York.

column1: I wanted 60 for Supreme Court and Cabinet
column2: but I didn't prevail
column3: Schumer told The Washington Post.

column1: Still
column2: he vowed opposition to some nominees
column3: however possible. ""If it's somebody who is out of the mainstream
column4: Schumer said
column5: ""we'll fight tooth and nail and use every tool we have.""

column1: The Senate has traditionally deferred to new presidents' wishes in filling out their Cabinets
column2: approving many nominees without bothering to even take formal votes.

column1: Recent incoming presidents have had to withdraw only one or two Cabinet picks
column2: if any at all
column3: and the Senate has voted to outright reject just three nominees in the past 100 years
column4: according to the Senate historian.

column1: But Democrats are in no mood to be deferential to Trump after Republicans
column2: in their view
column3: broke with tradition by obstructing Obama Supreme Court pick Merrick Garland for nine months and fought the confirmation of his second attorney general
column4: Loretta Lynch.

column1: And they say Trump has chosen blatantly provocative or unqualified nominees
column2: instead of trying to find common ground in a divided country.

column4: told MSNBC on Friday of Trump's decision to name Puzder to head the department responsible for protecting workers. "	0
